      Constructions of two polycatenanes and one polypseudo-rotaxane by discrete tetrahedral cages and stool-like building units
      Jiang, Long; Ju, Ping; Meng, Xian-Rui; Kuang, Xiao-Jun; Lu, Tong-Bu
      Scientific Reports (2012), 2 (), 668/1-668/5, 5 pp.CODEN: SRCEC3; ISSN:2045-2322. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Mech. interlocked mols., such as catenanes and rotaxanes, are of great interest due to their fascinating structures and potential applications, while such mols. were mainly restricted to comprising components of interlocked rings or polygons. The constructions of infinite polycatenanes and polyrotaxanes by discrete cages remain great challenge and only two infinite polycatenanes fabricated by discrete cages are reported so far, while the structures of polyrotaxanes and polypseudo-rotaxanes fabricated by discrete build units were not documented to date. Herein the authors report the first example of a two-dimensional (2D) polypseudo-rotaxane {[NiL]5(tcba)3(PF6)(H2O)2} [2; L = 1,3-bis(2-aminoethyl)-1,3-propanediamine, H3tcba = tris(4-carboxybenzyl)amine] fabricated by stool-like build units, the second example of a 1-dimensional (1D) polycatenane {[NiL]4(Htcba)4(H2O)2} (1) and the second example of a three-dimensional (3D) polycatenane {H[NiL]6(tcba)4(ClO4)} (3), which were assembled by discrete tetrahedral cages. The pores of dehydrated 3-dimensional polycatenane are dynamic and display size-dependent adsorption/desorption behaviors of alcs.

      The porous metal-org. framework (MOF) PCM-4, based on tris(para-carboxylated) triphenylphosphine oxide, contains atypical, polar org. substituents; the material exhibits a hysteretic sorption of Ar, N2 and O2, and demonstrates the advantage of ligands of this type.

      Microporous Lanthanide-Organic Frameworks with Open Metal Sites: Unexpected Sorption Propensity and Multifunctional Properties
      Lee, Woo Ram; Ryu, Dae Won; Lee, Jin Wuk; Yoon, Jung Hee; Koh, Eui Kwan; Hong, Chang Seop
      Inorganic Chemistry (2010), 49 (11), 4723-4725CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Isostructural lanthanide-org. frameworks {[Ln(TPO)(DMF)]·(DMF)(H2O)n, Ln = Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd; n = 1.5 or 2} were prepd. by a solvothermal reaction of the corresponding metal ions and the phosphine-oxide-based tricarboxylate ligand (tris(4-carboxyphenyl)phosphine oxide = TPO). The gravimetric gas uptake of the desolvated compds. was unexpectedly increased when going from Nd3+ to Gd3+, which is assocd. with the enhanced surface areas and electrostatic interactions between exposed metal ions and gas mols. with quadrupole moments.

      High capacity CO2 adsorption in a Mg(II)-based phosphine oxide coordination material
      Bohnsack, Alisha M.; Ibarra, Ilich A.; Hatfield, Peter W.; Yoon, Ji-Woong; Hwang, Young-Kyu; Chang, Jong-San; Humphrey, Simon M.
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2011), 47 (17), 4899-4901CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The new porous phosphine coordination material, [Mg4(μ3-OH)2(tctpo)2(OH2)4] (PCM-11), is an unusual 8,4-connected coordination polymer with an open 3-dimensional pore structure, formed by reaction of Mg(II) with tris(p-carboxyphenyl)phosphine oxide (H3tctpo). The highly ionic nature of the metal-ligand bonding results in excellent thermal stability upon desolvation (>460°). PCM-11 is easily activated for small mol. sorption at low temp. without the requirement for solvent pre-exchange. It adsorbs 47.5% CO2 at 11.6 bar and 30°.

      Microwave-Assisted Synthesis of a Series of Lanthanide Metal-Organic Frameworks and Gas Sorption Properties
      Lin, Zu-Jin; Yang, Zhen; Liu, Tian-Fu; Huang, Yuan-Biao; Cao, Rong
      Inorganic Chemistry (2012), 51 (3), 1813-1820CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Isostructural microporous lanthanide metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) formulated as [Ln2(TPO)2(HCOO)]·(Me2NH2)·(DMF)4·(H2O)6 {Ln = Y (1), Sm (2), Eu (3), Gd (4), Tb (5), Dy (6), Ho (7), Er (8), Tm (9), Yb (10), and Lu (11); H3TPO = tris-(4-carboxylphenyl)phosphine oxide; DMF = DMF} was synthesized under microwave-assisted solvothermal reaction for 30 min. Alternatively, if a conventional solvothermal reaction is carried out under the same temp., a much longer time (3 days) is needed for the same phase in similar yield. Structure anal. reveals that the framework is a 4,8-connected network with point symbol (410·616·82) (45·6)2, which is the subnet of alb net. Thermal gravimetric analyses performed on as-synthesized MOFs reveal that the frameworks have high thermal stability. The luminescent properties of 2, 3, 5, and 6 were studied and show characteristic emissions for Sm(III), Eu(III), Tb(III), and Dy(III) at room temp., resp. Gas sorption properties of desolvated 1 and 3 were studied by exptl. measuring N, Ar, CO2, methane, and H sorption isotherms. The resulting materials show high and preferential CO2 adsorption over N2 gas at ambient temp., indicating that the present materials can be applied in a CO2 capture process.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Lee, Woo Ram; Ryu, Dae Won; Phang, Won Ju; Park, Ji Hye; Hong, Chang Seop

      A paddle-wheel-type Cu metal-org. framework [Cu(HTPO)].2DMF.1.5H2O (CuHTPO) (H3TPO = tris(4-carboxyphenyl)phosphineoxide) involving hydrogen bonds in the network was used to obtain composite systems with different metal ions of Zn2+ and Tb3+. The framework stability and crystal transformation are affected by the charges of foreign cations.

      47
      Organic Vapor Sorption in a High Surface Area Dysprosium(III)-Phosphine Oxide Coordination Material
      Ibarra, Ilich A.; Yoon, Ji Woong; Chang, Jong-San; Lee, Su Kyoung; Lynch, Vincent M.; Humphrey, Simon M.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2012), 51 (22), 12242-12247CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      PCM-16 is a phosphine coordination material comprised of Dy(III) and triphenylphosphine oxide, which displays the highest reported CO2 BET surface area for a Ln(III) coordination polymer of 1511 m2 g-1. PCM-16 also adsorbs 2.7% H2 and 65.1% O2 at 77 K and 0.97 bar. The adsorption-desorption behavior of org. vapors were studied in PCM-16 to probe the nature of certain host-guest interactions in the pores. Arom. and polar guest species showed high uptakes and marked adsorption/desorption hysteresis, while aliph. vapors were less easily adsorbed. The surface area of PCM-16 could be increased significantly (to 1814 m2 g-1) via exchange of Me2NH2+ cations in the pores with smaller NH4+ groups.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhsF2ktb7M&md5=a57a019ff08ba39614f36d29da731486
    48. 48
      Chou, W.-N.; Pomerantz, M. J. Org. Chem. 1991, 56, 2762– 2769
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      48
      N-phenyl-P,P,P-triarylphospha-λ5-azenes, triarylphosphines, and triarylphosphine oxides. Substituent effects on nitrogen-15, phosphorus-31, and carbon-13 NMR spectra
      Chou, Whe Narn; Pomerantz, Martin
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (1991), 56 (8), 2762-9CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
      The syntheses and 15N, 31P, and 13C NMR spectra of a series of N-phenyl-P,P,P-triarylphospha-λ5-azenes (p-RC6H4)3P:NPh (I, R = H, Cl, NMe2, etc.) and the 31P and 13C NMR spectra of the corresponding series of triarylphosphines (p-RC6H4)3P (II) and triarylphosphine oxides (p-RC6H4)3PO (III) are reported. The substituent effects on the chem. shifts can be best accommodated and rationalized by use of a model for system I whereby the dipole of the aryl group and its pendant R group polarizes the rest of the mol. This includes the P and N atoms and Ph ring, where an electron-withdrawing R group increases the electron d. on the P, N, and ipso C-1 while decreasing the electron d. on C-3 and C-4 of the N-Ph ring. A similar polarization pattern for the phosphine oxide series III is suggested. In the phosphine series II, the chem. shift data is consistent with the lone electron pair on the phosphorus atom delocalizing into the aryl rings. The coupling const. data, in particular 1JPN for series I and 1JPC for series I-III, were examd. with use of the Hammett monosubstituent parameter and the Taft dual-substituent parameter approaches.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3MXhvVGlsLk%253D&md5=0e21e93996097c675b405ee96c9613cb

    51. 51
      Sheldrick, G. M. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. A 2008, 64, 112– 122
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      51
      A short history of SHELX
      Sheldrick, George M.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
      An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsVGhurzO&md5=8f91f10be4a9df74b2a9dad522c71e6e
    52. 52

      Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON:

      Spek, A. L. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2003, 36, 7– 13
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      52
      Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
      Spek, A. L.
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
      The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlChtw%253D%253D&md5=0a85de2407551632bb287508534904e2
    53. 53
      Zhang, S.-Q.; Jiang, F.-L.; Wu, M.-Y.; Ma, J.; Bu, Y.; Hong, M.-C. Cryst. Growth Des. 2012, 12, 1452– 1463
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      53
      Assembly of Discrete One-, Two-, and Three-Dimensional Zn(II) Complexes Containing Semirigid V-Shaped Tricarboxylate Ligands
      Zhang, Shu-Quan; Jiang, Fei-Long; Wu, Ming-Yan; Ma, Jie; Bu, Yang; Hong, Mao-Chun
      Crystal Growth & Design (2012), 12 (3), 1452-1463CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Hydrothermal reaction of zinc nitrate, 4-(4-carboxyphenoxy)phthalic acid (H3cpop), and different N-donor coligands has afforded six novel supramol. compds., in which the nature of the neutral coligands plays a crucial structure-directing role. [Zn(Hcpop)(H2O)3]2 (1) and [Zn(Hcpop)(phen)(H2O)]2 (2, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) form three-dimensional (3D) supramol. frameworks linked by H-bonds and π-π interactions based on discrete mols. Similarly, [Zn2(Hcpop)2(4,4'-bpy)3(H2O)2]n·4nH2O (3) possesses a 3-dimensional supramol. structure, aggregated by interesting 1-dimensional (1D) armed-polyrotaxane chains. [Zn6(cpop)4(4,4'-bpy)2(H2O)2]n (4, 4,4'-bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine) exhibits a complicated 3-dimensional framework which can be rationalized as a (3,6,6)-connected trinodal net with a unique (4.62)2(42.69.83.10)(44.68.83) topol. [Zn3(cpop)2(bpdb)(H2O)2]n (5, bpdb = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene) is a 3-dimensional structure contg. two-dimensional (2D) metal-carboxylate layer motifs, which are further pillared by cpop3- and bpdb ligands to complete the structure. [Zn6(cpop)4(azpy)2(H2O)4]n (6, azpy = 4,4'-azopyridine) manifests a unique quadruple layer structure constructed from two types of bilayered architectures linked by Zn2+ ions and bridging azpy ligands. Solid-state properties such as thermal stability and the photoluminescence properties at room temp. for these complexes also were systematically studied.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XosFamsA%253D%253D&md5=9235b204d2cb4ece3be465f7d76bc7ba
    54. 54
      Rowsell, J. L. C.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 1304– 1315
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      54
      Effects of Functionalization, Catenation, and Variation of the Metal Oxide and Organic Linking Units on the Low-Pressure Hydrogen Adsorption Properties of Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (4), 1304-1315CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The dihydrogen adsorption isotherms of eight metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), measured at 77 K up to a pressure of 1 atm, were examd. for correlations with their structural features. All materials display approx. Type I isotherms with no hysteresis, and satn. was not reached for any of the materials under these conditions. Among the six iso-reticular MOFs (IRMOFs) studied, the catenated materials exhibit the largest capacities on a molar basis, up to 9.8 H2 per formula unit. The addn. of functional groups (-Br, -NH2, -C2H4-) to the phenylene links of IRMOF-1 (MOF-5), or their replacement with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene moieties in IRMOF-20, altered the adsorption behavior by a minor amt. despite large variations in the pore vols. of the resulting materials. But replacement of the metal oxide units with those contg. coordinatively unsatd. metal sites resulted in greater H2 uptake. The enhanced affinities of these materials, MOF-74 and HKUST-1, were further demonstrated by calcn. of the isosteric heats of adsorption, which were larger across much of the range of coverage examd., compared to those of representative IRMOFs. Probably under low-loading conditions, the H2 adsorption behavior of MOFs can be improved by imparting larger charge gradients on the metal oxide units and adjusting the link metrics to constrict the pore dimensions; however, a large pore vol. is still a prerequisite feature.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XitV2msg%253D%253D&md5=76a0797beec956e59ca2ddf029f5a386

      Porous cobalt(II)-organic frameworks with corrugated walls: structurally robust gas-sorption materials
      Humphrey, Simon M.; Chang, Jong-San; Jhung, Sung Hwa; Yoon, Ji Woong; Wood, Paul T.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (1+2), 272-275CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The porous coordination solids CUK-1 (Co purple, C gray, N blue, O red/pink) and CUK-2 are synthesized from unsym. ligands and CoII ions. Even after the removal of cocrystd. guests, the host frameworks are exceptionally stable. CUK-1 shows a high capacity for H2 adsorption and is one of very few materials capable of sepg. N2 from O2. Crystal structures of the above compds. have been described.

      56
      Hydrogen Sorption in Functionalized Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Millward, Andrew R.; Park, Kyo Sung; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (18), 5666-5667CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Five porous metal-org. frameworks based on linking zinc oxide clusters with benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate, naphthalene-2,6-dicarboxylate, 4,5,9,10-tetrahydropyrene-2,7-dicarboxylate, 2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene-1,4-dicarboxylate, or benzene-1,3,5-tris(4-benzoate) were synthesized in gram-scale quantities to measure their hydrogen uptake properties. Hydrogen adsorption isotherms measured at 77 K show a distinct dependence of uptake on the nature of the link. At 1 atm, the materials sorb between 4.2 and 9.3 mols. of H2 per formula unit. The results imply a trend in hydrogen uptake with the no. of rings in the org. moiety.

      Kaye, S. S.; Long, J. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127, 6506– 6507
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      57
      Hydrogen Storage in the Dehydrated Prussian Blue Analogues M3[Co(CN)6]2 (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn)
      Kaye, Steven S.; Long, Jeffrey R.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (18), 6506-6507CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The porosity and hydrogen storage properties for the dehydrated Prussian blue analogs M3[Co(CN)6]2 (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) are reported. Argon sorption isotherms measured at 87 °K afford BET surface areas ranging from 560 m2/g for Ni3[Co(CN)6]2 to 870 m2/g for Mn3[Co(CN)6]2; the latter value is comparable to the highest surface area reported for any known zeolite. All six compds. show significant hydrogen sorption at 77 °K and 890 torr, varying from 1.4% and 0.018 kg H2/L for Zn3[Co(CN)6]2 to 1.8% and 0.025 kg H2/L for Cu3[Co(CN)6]2. Fits to the sorption data employing the Langmuir-Freundlich equation give max. uptake quantities, resulting in a predicted storage capacity of 2.1% and 0.029 kg H2/L for Cu3[Co(CN)6]2 at satn. Enthalpies of adsorption for the frameworks were calcd. from hydrogen isotherms measured at 77 and 87 °K and found to increase with M varying in the order Mn < Zn < Fe < Co < Cu < Ni. In all cases, the binding enthalpies, which lie at 5.3-7.4 kJ/mol, are higher than the 4.7-5.2 kJ/mol measured for Zn4O(1,4-benzenedicarboxylate)3.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

The H2 and CH4 adsorption enthalpies of PCN-9 are among the highest reported thus far.

      Suh, M. P.; Park, H. J.; Prasad, T. K.; Lim, D.-W. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 782– 835
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      59
      Hydrogen Storage in Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Suh, Myunghyun Paik; Park, Hye Jeong; Prasad, Thazhe Kootteri; Lim, Dae-Woon
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 782-835CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. MOFs have versatile structures, high surface areas and high pore vols. - they can be regarded as good candidate materials for H storage. There are many MOFs that have high H adsorption capacities at low temps., typically at 77 or 87 K. The highest H storage capacity reported so far is 99.5 mg/g at 77K and 56 bar for NU-100. However, the high H capacities of MOFs at cryogenic temps. decrease as the temp. increases to room temp. This is because the H adsorption in MOFs is weak physisorption and the interaction energies between the H mols. and frameworks are low. To develop MOFs as H storage materials that meet the U.S.DOE targets for an on-board hydrogen system, a serious challenge is still present in the design and synthesis of the MOF materials. We may expect that highly stable MOFs having a large surface area and pore vol., together with many open metal sites and embedded catalysts for hydrogen spillover, would provide some pos. results for H storage at ambient temp.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs1GlsbjM&md5=dd1f08beefd27cce77d88e466551c1af

      Vaidhyanathan, R.; Iremonger, S. S.; Shimizu, G. K. H.; Boyd, P. G.; Alavi, S.; Woo, T. K. Science 2010, 330, 650– 653
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      60
      Direct Observation and Quantification of CO2 Binding Within an Amine-Functionalized Nanoporous Solid
      Vaidhyanathan, Ramanathan; Iremonger, Simon S.; Shimizu, George K. H.; Boyd, Peter G.; Alavi, Saman; Woo, Tom K.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 330 (6004), 650-653CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Understanding the mol. details of CO2-sorbent interactions is crit. for the design of better carbon-capture systems. Here the authors report crystallog. resoln. of CO2 mols. and their binding domains in a metal-org. framework functionalized with amine groups. Accompanying computational studies that modeled the gas sorption isotherms, high heat of adsorption, and CO2 lattice positions showed high agreement on all three fronts. The modeling apportioned specific binding interactions for each CO2 mol., including substantial cooperative binding effects among the guest mols. The validation of the capacity of such simulations to accurately model mol.-scale binding bodes well for the theory-aided development of amine-based CO2 sorbents. The anal. shows that the combination of appropriate pore size, strongly interacting amine functional groups, and the cooperative binding of CO2 guest mols. is responsible for the low-pressure binding and large uptake of CO2 in this sorbent material.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Tuning MOF CO2 Adsorption Properties via Cation Exchange
      An, Jihyun; Rosi, Nathaniel L.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (16), 5578-5579CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The pore vol. and BET surface area of bio-MOF-1 (a), Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O·Me2NH2, is systematically modified via postsynthetic cation exchange with either tetramethylammonium, tetraethylammonium, or tetrabutylammonium cations to yield Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O·Me4N (b), Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O·2Et4N (c), and Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O·Bu4N (d), resp. The impact that pore vol. and BET surface area have on CO2 capacity is evaluated, and it is found that materials with intermediate porosity (b and c) have the largest CO2 capacities under the conditions studied.

      Millward, A. R.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127, 17998– 17999
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      62
      Metal-Organic Frameworks with Exceptionally High Capacity for Storage of Carbon Dioxide at Room Temperature
      Millward, Andrew R.; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (51), 17998-17999CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) show high CO2 storage capacity at room temp. Gravimetric CO2 isotherms for MOF-2, MOF-505, Cu3(BTC)2, MOF-74, IRMOF-11, IRMOF-3, IRMOF-6, IRMOF-1 and MOF-177 are reported up to 42 bar. Type I isotherms are found in all cases except for MOFs based on Zn4O(O2C)6 clusters, which reveal a sigmoidal isotherm. The various pressures of the isotherm steps correlate with increasing pore size, which indicates potential for gas sepns. The amine functionality of the IRMOF-3 pore shows evidence of relatively increased affinity for CO2. Capacities qual. scale with surface area and range from 3.2 mmol/g for MOF-2 to 33.5 mmol/g (320 cm3(STP)/cm3, 147 wt %) for MOF-177, the highest CO2 capacity of any porous material reported.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1GktLnJ&md5=ad433b990b72836a16c8647c09ec85f2

      Myers, A. L.; Prausnitz, J. M.
      AIChE Journal (1965), 11 (1), 121-7CODEN: AICEAC; ISSN:0001-1541.
      Adsorption equil. for components in a gaseous mixt. can be calcd. by using only data for pure-component adsorption equil. at the same temp. for the same adsorbent. Predicted isotherms give good agreement with exptl. data for mixts. of CH4-C2H6 and of C2H4CO2 on activated C, and of CO-O2 and of C3H8-C3H6 on silica gel.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Construction of a Polyhedral Metal-Organic Framework via a Flexible Octacarboxylate Ligand for Gas Adsorption and Separation
      Lin, Zu-Jin; Huang, Yuan-Biao; Liu, Tian-Fu; Li, Xiang-Ying; Cao, Rong
      Inorganic Chemistry (2013), 52 (6), 3127-3132CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A flexible octacarboxylate ligand, tetrakis[(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)oxamethyl]methane (H8X), has been used to construct a highly porous metal-org. framework (In2X)(Me2NH2)2(DMF)9(H2O)5 (1), which is comprised of octahedral and cuboctahedral cages and shows a rare (4,8)-connected scu topol. Gas adsorption studies of N2, H2 on the activated 1 at 77 K reveal a Langmuir surface area of 1707 m2 g-1, a BET surface area of 1555 m2 g-1, a total pore vol. of 0.62 cm3 g-1, and a H2 uptake of 1.49 wt.% at 1 bar and 3.05 wt.% at 16 bar. CO2, CH4, and N2 adsorption studies at 195, 273, 285, and 298 K and also ideal adsorbed soln. theory (IAST) calcns. demonstrate that 1 has high selectivities of CO2 over CH4 and N2. The resulting framework represents a MOF with the highest gas uptakes and gas selectivities (CO2 over CH4 and N2) constructed by flexible ligands.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXjs1yisb8%253D&md5=8b6ba2ec23c80c89c913e8f5026c7de2
    65. 65
      Xu, Q.; Liu, D. H.; Yang, Q. Y.; Zhong, C. L.; Mi, J. G. J. Mater. Chem. 2010, 20, 706– 714
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      65
      Li-modified metal-organic frameworks for CO2/CH4 separation: a route to achieving high adsorption selectivity
      Xu, Qing; Liu, Dahuan; Yang, Qingyuan; Zhong, Chongli; Mi, Jianguo
      Journal of Materials Chemistry (2010), 20 (4), 706-714CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      In this work three Li-modified metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) were constructed from MOF-5, by substituting the H atoms with O-Li groups in the org. linkers. A multiscale approach combining grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation and d. functional theory (DFT) calcn. was adopted to investigate the sepn. of CO2/CH4 mixts. in these new Li-modified MOFs, as well as in a previously proposed Li-doped MOF-5 for hydrogen storage and the original MOF-5. The results show that the selectivity of CO2 from CH4/CO2 mixts. in Li-modified MOFs is greatly improved, due to the enhancement of electrostatic potential in the materials by the presence of the metals. One of the new Li-modified MOFs, chem-4Li, shows a higher CO2 selectivity than any other known MOFs. Therefore, this work provides a route to improve the sepn. performance of MOFs for gas mixts. with components that have large differences in dipole and/or quadrupole moments. In addn., the mechanisms for selectivity enhancement in the Li-modified MOFs were elucidated at the mol. level, and we found that the location of doped metals can change the adsorption sites for CO2, and in turn may change the active sites in MOFs when used as catalysts.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

    66. 66

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      66
      Understanding gas separation in metal-organic frameworks using computer modeling
      Liu, Da-Huan; Zhong, Chong-Li
      Journal of Materials Chemistry (2010), 20 (46), 10308-10318CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a new family of nanoporous materials that combine the advantages of both inorg. and org. materials with great variety in functionality, pore size and topol. Gas sepn. is one of the fields that the first practical application of MOFs may be applied to; however, the study of MOFs as adsorbents in gas sepn. is still in its early stage, and their sepn. characteristics are not quite clear. Here, we summarize the recent advances on gas sepn. in MOFs using computer modeling, and show how computer modeling can help to understand the sepn. characteristics of MOFs. In addn., several strategies are proposed to improve the sepn. efficiency of MOFs, which are expected to be useful for designing new MOFs with improved sepn. performance for targeted properties.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      This study shows that triads using a Pt diimine bid(acetylide) chromophore such as I (PTZ = phenothiazine) can be constructed and that the chromophore MLCT excited state can be used for photoinduced charge-transfer processes.

      Supramolecular Recognition. Terpyridyl Palladium and Platinum Molecular Clefts and Their Association with Planar Platinum Complexes
      Goshe, Andrew J.; Steele, Ian M.; Bosnich, B.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2003), 125 (2), 444-451CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Mol. receptors, consisting of either two parallel cofacially disposed terpyridyl-Pd-Cl+ or terpyridyl-Pt-Cl+ units, are described. Concerted rotation of these units about the mol. spacer can alter their sepn. between 6.4 and 7.2 Å to accommodate the dimensions of mol. guests. Neutral and anionic planar complexes of Pt(II) were studied as guests to det. if metal-metal interaction between the host and guest metals could stabilize host-guest assocn. With a neutral guest, host-guest formation is signaled by a color change from light yellow to deep red. For one of the anionic guests, a visible absorption band appears upon host-guest formation with the Pt receptor that is ascribed to transitions assocd. with a Pt-Pt interaction. The assocn. consts. found for the neutral guest with the Pd and Pt receptors are large, suggesting that metal-metal interaction contributes to the mol. recognition. The structures of the host-(neutral)guest complexes in soln. were detd. by 1H NOESY spectra. A crystal structure of the Pt host-(neutral)guest complex is the same as that found in soln. and confirms the presence of a Pt-Pt interaction. Temp.-dependent 195Pt NMR spectra in soln. provide a quant. est. of the conformational interconversions of the free Pt receptor.

      Synthesis, Structure, and Electroluminescence of BR2q (R = Et, Ph, 2-Naphthyl and q = 8-Hydroxyquinolato)
      Wu, Qingguo; Esteghamatian, Mohammad; Hu, Nan-Xing; Popovic, Zoran; Enright, Gary; Tao, Ye; D'Iorio, Marie; Wang, Suning
      Chemistry of Materials (2000), 12 (1), 79-83CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      Three 8-hydroxyquinolato (q) boron compds. B(C2H5)2q (1), BPh2q (2), and B(2-naph)2q (3) have been synthesized by the reaction of 8-hydroxyquinoline with an appropriate BR3 compd. Compds. 1-3 have a tetrahedral geometry as demonstrated by the structure of 1 detd. by a single-crystal x-ray diffraction anal. Compds. 1-3 emit a green-blue color at λmax = 495-500 nm when irradiated by UV light. The electroluminescent (EL) properties of 2 and 3 were examd. by fabricating EL devices using 2 and 3 as the light-emitting layer, resp. The devices of 2 produce a yellow-green light with broad emission spectra, attributed to the formation of an exciplex of 2 with the N,N'-di-1-naphthyl-N,N'-diphenylbenzidine (NPB) in the hole transport layer while the intrinsic EL emission of compd. 3 was obsd. Both 2 and 3 were good electron transport materials in EL devices.

      Allendorf, M. D.; Bauer, C. A.; Bhaktaa, R. K.; Houka, R. J. T. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2009, 38, 1330– 1352

      71
      Luminescent metal-organic frameworks
      Allendorf, M. D.; Bauer, C. A.; Bhakta, R. K.; Houk, R. J. T.
      Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1330-1352CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review; metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) display a wide range of luminescent behaviors resulting from the multifaceted nature of their structure. In this crit. review we discuss the origins of MOF luminosity, which include the linker, the coordinated metal ions, antenna effects, excimer and exciplex formation, and guest mols. The literature describing these effects is comprehensively surveyed, including a categorization of each report according to the type of luminescence obsd. Finally, we discuss potential applications of luminescent MOFs. This review will be of interest to researchers and synthetic chemists attempting to design luminescent MOFs, and those engaged in the extension of MOFs to applications such as chem., biol., and radiation detection, medical imaging, and electro-optical devices.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Novel Bis(4,4'-dipyridylamine) Ligand with a Flexible Butadiyne Linker: Syntheses, Structures, and Photoluminescence of d10 Metal Coordination Polymers
      Ding, Caixia; Li, Xing; Ding, Yubin; Li, Xin; Ng, Seik Weng; Xie, Yongshu
      Crystal Growth & Design (2012), 12 (7), 3465-3473CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      The design and syntheses of novel ligands are essential for developing coordination compds. with novel structures and interesting properties. The authors designed and synthesized a novel ligand bis(4,4'-dipyridylaminophenylene)butadiyne (L) by attaching two 4,4'-dipyridylamine moieties to a flexible butadiyne linker. Starting from this novel ligand, seven coordination polymers [Zn2L(HCOO)3(OH)]n (1), [Cd2L2Cl4]n·3nDMF·3nH2O (2), [CdLBr2]n (3), [Cd6L3(SO4)6]n·4nMeCN (4), [Hg2LBr4]n·3nCH2Cl2·nH2O (5), [Cu2LI2]n·0.5nCH2Cl2 (6), and [Ag2L(H2O)2]n(NO3)2n·2nH2O (7) were synthesized. Single-crystal x-ray diffraction analyses revealed that two forms of the ligand crystals, L and L·0.5DMF present straight and bent conformations, resp., because of the flexibility of the butadiyne unit. A rich structural diversity was obsd. for its d10 metal complexes. Complexes 1 and 5 present ladder-like structures. In complexes 2 and 4, the ligand mols. are linked by metal atoms to afford 3-dimensional supramol. structures. It is noteworthy that the 3-dimensional structure of complex 4 consists of interesting infinite {Cd6(SO4)6}∞ chains, whereas complexes 3, 6, and 7 exhibit 2-dimensional network structures. In the crystal of complex 7, each ligand links four metal ions and each Ag ion bridges two ligands, giving undulated 2-dimensional sheets with large cavities composed of 66-membered metallomacrocycles, which are interpenetrated by three other such 2-dimensional sheets, affording a 4-fold interpenetrated structure. In summary, the complex structures are dependent on the metal ions and the anions. The flexibility of the butadiyne moiety provides addnl. means for modulating the structures. Solid state photoluminescence of the free ligand and the complexes shows emission maxima within the range of 420-515 nm, which can be modulated by the conformations of the ligand in addn. to the variation of the metal ions and anions, and the introduction of the butadiyne unit has a bathochromic effect.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Structures, photoluminescence, up-conversion, and magnetism of two- and three-dimensional rare-Earth coordination polymers with multicarboxylate linkages
      Yang, Jin; Yue, Qi; Li, Guo-Dong; Cao, Jun-Jun; Li, Guang-Hua; Chen, Jie-Sheng
      Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (7), 2857-2865CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Four new rare-earth compds., [Eu(NDC)1.5(DMF)2] (1), [Nd2(NDC)3(DMF)4]·H2O (2), [La2(NDC)3(DMF)4]·0.5H2O (3), and [Eu(BTC)(H2O)] (4), where NDC = 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate, BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, were synthesized through preheating and cooling-down crystn. Compds. 1-3 possess similar two-dimensional structures in which the NDC ligands link MIII (M = La, Nd, and Eu) ions of two adjacent double chains constructed by NDC ligands and dinuclear MIII building units. In compd. 4, the EuIII ion is seven-coordinated by O atoms from six BTC ligands and one terminal H2O mol. in a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal coordination environment. If the BTC ligand and the EuIII ion are regarded as six-connected nodes, resp., the structure of compd. 4 can be well described as a three-dimensional six-connected net. Also, compds. 1 and 4 exhibit strong red luminescence upon 355-nm excitation. Compd. 2 displays interesting emissions in the near-IR region, and yellow (580 nm) pumping of this compd. results in UV and intense blue emissions through an up-conversion process. The magnetic properties of compds. 1, 2, and 4 were studied through measurement of their magnetic susceptibilities at 4-300 K.

      Series of 2D and 3D Coordination Polymers Based on 1,2,3,4-Benzenetetracarboxylate and N-Donor Ligands: Synthesis, Topological Structures, and Photoluminescent Properties
      Zhang, Lai-Ping; Ma, Jian-Fang; Yang, Jin; Pang, Yuan-Yuan; Ma, Ji-Cheng
      Inorganic Chemistry (2010), 49 (4), 1535-1550CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Nine new coordination polymers, namely, [Mn2(L)(H2O)4]·H2O (1), [Cd(L)0.5(H2O)] (2), [Zn5(L)2(μ3-O)2(H2O)4]·2H2O (3), [Zn4(L)2(μ3-O)2][Zn(H2O)6]·2H2O (4), [Zn2(L)(biim-4)0.5(H2O)3]·H2O (5), [Cd2(L)(bpy)(H2O)]·2H2O·0.5(CH3CH2OH) (6), [Cu2(H2L)2(bpy)2] (7), [Cu2(L)(bpy)(H2O)] (8), and [Cu2(L)(bpy)1.5(H2O)2.5] (9), where H4L = 1,2,3,4-benzenetetracarboxylic acid, biim-4 = 1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole), and bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine, were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Compd. 1 displays a rare trinodal (3,4,7)-connected (42·6)(45·6)(47·68·86) topol. 2 Possesses an α-Po net. 3 Is a novel 3-dimensional framework based on pentanuclear ZnII clusters. By adjustment of the pH values of the reaction mixt. of 3 with a Na2CO3 soln., a structurally different compd., 4, was obtained, which exhibits a 3-dimensional porous framework with the [Zn(H2O)6]2+ cations located in the channels. 5 Is an unusual example of a trinodal (3,5)-connected network with a Schlafli symbol of (42·6)(62·8)(42·62·85·10), whereas 6, contg. tetranuclear CdII clusters, shows a rare (4,6)-connected (44·62)2(44·610·8) topol. 7 Exhibits a unique polythreading network, while 8 displays a scarce trinodal (3,4,5)-connected self-penetrating network. In comparison with 8, the chiral compd. 9 possesses an unprecedented tetranodal (2,4)-connected (7)(75·11)(62·73·8)2(6·74 × 10)2 topol. The effects of the carboxylate ligands, the pH values, the reaction temps., the central metals, and the neutral ligands were elucidated. The IR spectra, TGA, and luminescent properties for the compds. were also studied.

      Metal-organic frameworks constructed from mixed-ligand 1,2,3,4-tetra-(4-pyridyl)-butane and benzene-polycarboxylate acids: syntheses, structures and physical properties
      Lin, Jian-Guo; Zang, Shuang-Quan; Tian, Zhen-Fang; Li, Yi-Zhi; Xu, Yan-Yan; Zhu, Hui-Zhen; Meng, Qing-Jin
      CrystEngComm (2007), 9 (10), 915-921CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Three novel coordination polymers, [Mn(TPB)0.5(IPA)(H2O)2]n (1), [Zn1.5(TPB)0.5(TMA)(H2O)·(H2O)]n (2), and [Co(TPB)0.5(PMA)0.5(H2O)2·(H2O)]n (3) (TPB = 1,2,3,4-tetra-(4-pyridyl)-butane; H2IPA = isophthalic acid; H3TMA = trimesic acid; and H4PMA = pyromellitic acid) were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and structurally characterized. Complex 1 features a 2-dimensional infinite layer framework consisting of bi-manganese clusters, which is further stacked along the [‾111] direction via strong interlayer π···π interactions to form a 3-dimensional supramol. architecture. Complex 2 has a 3-dimensional complicated framework comprised of two kinds of infinite 1-dimensional chains. The 3-dimensional framework of complex 3 possesses three topol. nonequivalent 4-connected nodes synchronously and exhibits an unprecedented (64·102)(42·84)(4·65)2 topol. The magnetic susceptibility data of complex 1 show strong antiferromagnetic interactions in the dinuclear Mn(II) units. Complex 2 exhibits strong fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temp. and may be suitable as a candidate of blue-fluorescent material.

      Syntheses and Structures of Four d10 Metal-Organic Frameworks Assembled with Aromatic Polycarboxylate and bix [bix = 1,4-Bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene]
      Wen, Lili; Li, Yizhi; Lu, Zhenda; Lin, Jianguo; Duan, Chunying; Meng, Qingjin
      Crystal Growth & Design (2006), 6 (2), 530-537CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Four novel cadmium(II) or zinc(II) metal coordination polymers [Cd2(2,3-pydc)2(bix)3·2H2O]n (1), [Cd2(μ2-OH2)(2,6-pydc)2(bix)]n (2), [Cd3(SIP)2(bix)4·8H2O]n (3) and [Zn2(SIP)(bix)3(OH)·2H2O]n (4) (bix = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene; 2,3-pydc = pyridine-2,3-dicarboxylate; 2,6-pydc = pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate; SIP = 5-sulfoisophthalate) have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and structurally characterized. Polymer 2 is a 2D infinite layer framework and the resulting 2D structure is interconnected by hydrogen-bond interactions to lead to a 3D supramol. architecture. Polymer 3 also possesses a 3D porous framework in which the most prominent cavities are parallel to the a- and b- directions and are filled with free water mols. Polymer 4 exhibits 4-fold interpenetration related by three different translation vectors. These four compds. exhibit strong fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temp. and could be significant in the field of photoactive materials.

      Syntheses, Structures, and Physical Properties of Three Novel Metal-Organic Frameworks Constructed from Aromatic Polycarboxylate Acids and Flexible Imidazole-Based Synthons
      Wen, Lili; Lu, Zhenda; Lin, Jianguo; Tian, Zhengfang; Zhu, Huizhen; Meng, Qingjin

      Kent, C. A.; Liu, D.; Ito, A.; Zhang, T.; Brennaman, M. K.; Meyer, T. J.; Lin, W. J. Mater. Chem. A 2013, 1, 14982– 14989
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      79
      Rapid energy transfer in non-porous metal-organic frameworks with caged Ru(bpy)32+ chromophores: oxygen trapping and luminescence quenching
      Kent, Caleb A.; Liu, Demin; Ito, Akitaka; Zhang, Teng; Brennaman, M. Kyle; Meyer, Thomas J.; Lin, Wenbin
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2013), 1 (47), 14982-14989CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Two non-porous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with caged Ru(bpy)32+ chromophores, [Ru(bpy)3][Zn2(C2O4)3] (1) and [Ru(bpy)3][NaAl(C2O4)3] (2), were synthesized and characterized. Their emission properties were studied by both steady-state and time-resolved luminescence measurements. Air-free microcrystals of 1 and 2 exhibit long-lived triplet metal-to-ligand charge transfer (3MLCT) excited states with lifetimes of 760 and 1305 ns, resp. Lifetimes are significantly shortened (to 92 ns for 1 and 144 ns for 2) by trapping of trace amts. of oxygen in the non-porous MOFs, presumably due to amplified luminescence quenching of Ru(bpy)32+*. Following MLCT excitation, Ru(bpy)32+*/Ru(bpy)32+ energy transfer migration in 1 and 2 results in efficient quenching of Ru(bpy)32+* by Os(bpy)32+ added as an energy transfer trap at doping levels of 0.2-1.0%. A kinetic anal. indicates that the three-dimensional chromophore connectivity in 1 and 2 provides a network for rapid excited state energy transfer migration among Ru(bpy)32+ units, ultimately, finding an Os(bpy)32+ trap site. These cryst. frameworks with caged chromophores have proven to be ideal systems for studying light harvesting processes in artificial supramol. systems.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhslOkt77K&md5=0a65aaf2d60b21e9ceeb2c8771cf99a4

      He, Y.-H.; Feng, Y.-L.; Lan, Y.-Z.; Wen, Y.-H. Cryst. Growth Des. 2008, 8, 3586– 3594
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      80
      Syntheses, Structures, and Photoluminescence of Four d10 Metal-Organic Frameworks Constructed from 3,5-Bis-oxyacetate-benzoic Acid
      He, Yin-Hua; Feng, Yun-Long; Lan, You-Zhao; Wen, Yi-Hang
      Crystal Growth & Design (2008), 8 (10), 3586-3594CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      A new multicarboxylate ligand, 3,5-bis(carboxymethoxy)benzoic acid (H3BOABA), was designed and introduced to construct novel metal-org. framework materials with potential luminescent properties. Four complexes, Zn2(BOABA)(OH)·H2O (1), Zn4(BOABA)2(4,4'-bipy)2(OH)2·H2O·0.5CH3CH2OH (2), Cd3(BOABA)2(H2O)6·6H2O (3), and Cd4(BOABA)2(phen)4(OH)2·H2O (4), were synthesized hydrothermally and structurally characterized. 1 Features an unusual 5-connected 46.64 uninodal net with both the dinuclear Zn(II) unit and the BOABA ligand being the square pyramidal nodes. 2 Presents an interesting three-dimensional (3,8)-connected network constructed from pillared undulate layers, which shows large 1-dimensional channels with dimensions of 11.97 × 13.82 Å along the a axis. The self-assembly between the Cd(II) ions and the BOABA ligand leads to a bilayer motif 3, whereas the presence of the auxiliary phen ligand results in a new compd. 4 with monolayer construction based on tetranuclear [Cd4(OH)2]6+ clusters. Photoluminescence studies reveal that these four complexes exhibit strong fluorescent emission bands in the solid state at room temp. The theoretic calcns. show that four complexes are indirect band gap semiconductors and the fluorescent emission peaks could be attributed to the ligand-ligand charge transfer. The thermal stabilities of these complexes were also examd.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtVSrtLjL&md5=1ea9d6e6a13e7001183a7f9cc6bc1621
    81. 81
      Zheng, S.-L.; Tong, M.-L.; Tan, S.-D.; Wang, Y.; Shi, J.-X.; Tong, Y.-X.; Lee, H.-K.; Chen, X.-M. Organometallics 2001, 20, 5319– 5325
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      81
      Syntheses, Structures, and Properties of Three Novel Coordination Polymers of Silver(I) Aromatic Carboxylates with Hexamethylenetetramine Exhibiting Unique Metal-π Interaction
      Zheng, Shao-Liang; Tong, Ming-Liang; Tan, Song-De; Wang, Yu; Shi, Jian-Xin; Tong, Ye-Xiang; Lee, Hung Kay; Chen, Xiao-Ming
      Organometallics (2001), 20 (25), 5319-5325CODEN: ORGND7; ISSN:0276-7333. (American Chemical Society)
      Three interesting coordination polymers, [Ag4(μ4-hmt)(μ4-η2-nda)2]·2H2O (1), [Ag2(μ-hmt)2(μ-bi-η2-bna)]·2H2O·MeCN (2), and [Ag2(μ4-hmt)(η2-hna)(MeCN)](hna)·H2O (3) (hmt = hexamethylenetetramine, nda = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate, bna = 2,2'-dihydroxy-1,1'-binaphthalene-3,3'-dicarboxylate, and hna = 1-hydroxy-2-naphthalenecarboxylate), were obtained from the reaction of silver(I) arom. carboxylates in MeCN soln. with hmt in CH2Cl2 soln. via the liq. diffusion method. In these complexes, the arom. carboxylates ligate to the metal atoms via a unique η2-coordination mode involving their arom. rings, in addn. to the normal coordination modes utilizing their carboxylate oxygen atoms. These complexes show interesting electronic properties similar to those reported for the silver(I) complexes of other polycyclic arom. compds. Both 1 and 2 exhibit a strong blue photoluminescence at room temp.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXotV2ksro%253D&md5=de3716f7dc414db9046c5a39b05f4357
    82. 82
      Zheng, S.-L.; Yang, J.-H.; Yu, X.-L.; Chen, X.-M.; Wong, W.-T. Inorg. Chem. 2004, 43, 830– 838
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      82
      Syntheses, Structures, Photoluminescence, and Theoretical Studies of d10 Metal Complexes of 2,2'-Dihydroxy-[1,1']binaphthalenyl-3,3'-dicarboxylate
      Zheng, Shao-Liang; Yang, Jin-Hua; Yu, Xiao-Lan; Chen, Xiao-Ming; Wong, Wing-Tak
      Inorganic Chemistry (2004), 43 (2), 830-838CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The free solvated ligand, H2bna·MeOH·H2O (1), and its dimeric complex, [Cd2(bna)2(H2O)6] (2) (bna = 2,2'-dihydroxy-[1,1']-binaphthalene-3,3'-dicarboxylate), were obtained by evapn. of the solns., while two new d10 metal-hydroxy cluster-based coordination polymers, [Cd8(OH)4(H2O)10(bna)6]·17H2O (3) and [Hpy]2[Zn4(OH)2(H2O)2(bna)4]·2H2O·2MeCN (4), were obtained by a hydrothermal route. All the compds. were characterized by x-ray crystallog. and photoluminescence measurements. Compd. 1 consists of a three-dimensional, H-bonded supramol. array, 2 exhibits a dimeric mol. featuring a square motif organized by two Cd(II) atoms and two bna ligands each at the corner, and 3 contains unprecedented [Cd8(μ3-OH)2(μ-OH)2(μ-H2O)2]12+ octanuclear metallacrown cores which are interlinked through bna to afford a two-dimensional structure, while 4 features layers with butterfly-shaped [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ clusters. All the complexes display photoluminescent properties in the blue/green range. The manifestation of photoluminescence, as probed by MO calcns. performed on the complexes and also on hypothetical multinuclear complexes, is attributed to a ligand-to-metal charge-transfer mechanism. In addn. to presenting a new approach for the study of the photoluminescent properties of metal-cluster-based coordination polymers by using simple model compds., the study also reveals the dominant role of the structure of the ligand over that of the d10 metal-hydroxy (or oxy) cluster and the presence of the cluster significantly increasing the emission lifetime.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXnt1w%253D&md5=e62d73a4481385bcf409a5682ce12b75

      1. 1
        O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 675– 702
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Deconstructing the Crystal Structures of Metal-Organic Frameworks and Related Materials into Their Underlying Nets
        O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 675-702CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Redn. of complex crystal structures of metal-org. frameworks and related materials to an underlying topol. is discussed. An approach to identify vertices of underlying nets is presented.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtFOmtr7L&md5=201baa336aa2d3edcb2099a649e840fe
      2. 2
        Sumida, K.; Rogow, D. L.; Mason, J. A.; Mcdonald, T. M.; Bloch, E. D; Herm, Z. R.; Bae, T.-H.; Long, J. R. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 724– 781
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        Carbon Dioxide Capture in Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Sumida, Kenji; Rogow, David L.; Mason, Jarad A.; McDonald, Thomas M.; Bloch, Eric D.; Herm, Zoey R.; Bae, Tae-Hyun; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 724-781CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        An extensive review is given on progress made in the capture of CO2 from power plant emissions, briefly considering also the CO2 storage (sequestration) of the enormous quantities of CO2 that would be obtained as a result of a successful capture framework. The main existing CO2 capture technologies are discussed in the context of capture performance considerations of aq. alkanolamine solns. and porous solids such as zeolites and activated carbons. Schematic diagrams are presented of idealized temp. swing adsorption, pressure swing adsorption, and vacuum swing adsorption processes for regenerating solid adsorbent in a fixed-bed column. The structural features and CO2 adsorption characteristics of isoreticular metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are discussed in detail. The high-pressure adsorption capacities of 36 MOF and the lower-pressure adsorption capacities of many more MOF, at 293-319 K, are tabulated. The various types of functionalities that have been explored to date for prepg. materials with enhanced CO2 capture performance are outlined, including amines, strongly polarizing org. functionalities, and exposed metal cation sites. The synthesis of continuous films of MOF and their use in membranes for gas sepn. are examd., with the tabulation of the CO2 sepn. performance of MOF mixed-matrix membranes. A final section outlines main issues that need to be addressed to achieve next-generation materials capable of fulfilling the criteria required for the gas sepns. relevant to post-combustion CO2 capture, pre-combustion CO2 capture, and oxy-fuel combustion.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs12hsLzE&md5=eb8236e7dfe12981387c71415374f958
      3. 3
        Chen, B. L.; Eddaoudi, M.; Hyde, S. T.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2001, 291, 1021– 1023
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3
        Interwoven metal-organic framework on a periodic minimal surface with extra-large pores
        Chen, Banglin; Eddaoudi, M.; Hyde, S. T.; O'Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2001), 291 (5506), 1021-1023CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        A strategy for the design of highly porous and structurally stable networks makes use of metal-org. building blocks that can be assembled on a triply periodic P-minimal geometric surface to produce structures that are interpenetrating-more accurately considered as interwoven. The authors used 4,4',4''-benzene-1,3,5-triyltribenzoic acid (H3BTB), Cu(NO3)2e, and DMF to prep. Cu3(BTB)2(H2O)3·(DMF)9(H2O)2 (MOF-14), whose structure reveals a pair of interwoven metal-org. frameworks that are mutually reinforced. The structure contains remarkably large pores, 16.4 Å in diam., in which voluminous amts. of gases and org. solvents can be reversibly sorbed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXhtFGlu7s%253D&md5=a9c2b80ba2f1b825ee2a55278ef5fe92
      4. 4
        Li, J.-R.; Sculley, J.; Zhou, H.-C. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 869– 932
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4
        Metal-Organic Frameworks for Separations
        Li, Jian-Rong; Sculley, Julian; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 869-932CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. This article reviews the metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), a new class of porous solid materials. Their performances for applications in sepns. and purifications is attracting intense interest of researchers working in the fields of chem., chem. engineering, materials science, and others. Despite being in its infancy, the research progress in this subject has already shown that MOFs are promising for sepn. applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXht1OnsbbL&md5=635f36e2682f7fbc651f5021d591a1cf
      5. 5
        Liu, J.; Thallapally, P. K.; McGrail, B. P.; Brown, D. R.; Liu, J. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2012, 41, 2308– 2322
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Progress in adsorption-based CO2 capture by metal-organic frameworks
        Liu, Jian; Thallapally, Praveen K.; McGrail, B. Peter; Brown, Daryl R.; Liu, Jun
        Chemical Society Reviews (2012), 41 (6), 2308-2322CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have recently attracted intense research interest because of their permanent porous structures, large surface areas, and potential applications as novel adsorbents. The recent progress in adsorption-based CO2 capture by MOFs is reviewed and summarized in this crit. review. CO2 adsorption in MOFs has been divided into two sections, adsorption at high pressures and selective adsorption at approx. atm. pressures. Keys to CO2 adsorption in MOFs at high pressures and low pressures are summarized to be pore vols. of MOFs, and heats of adsorption, resp. Many MOFs have high CO2 selectivities over N2 and CH4. Water effects on CO2 adsorption in MOFs are presented and compared with benchmark zeolites. In addn., strategies appeared in the literature to enhance CO2 adsorption capacities and/or selectivities in MOFs have been summarized into three main categories, catenation and interpenetration, chem. bonding enhancement, and electrostatic force involvement. Besides the advantages, two main challenges of using MOFs in CO2 capture, the cost of synthesis and the stability toward water vapor, have been analyzed and possible solns. and path forward have been proposed to address the two challenges as well (150 refs.).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XivFWlsbo%253D&md5=0ff1149f94a6e21a49a6591786eac483
      6. 6
        Shimomura, S.; Higuchi, M.; Matsuda, R.; Yoneda, K.; Hijikata, Y.; Kubota, Y.; Mita, Y.; Kim, J.; Takata, M.; Kitagawa, S. Nat. Chem. 2010, 2, 633– 637
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6
        Selective sorption of oxygen and nitric oxide by an electron-donating flexible porous coordination polymer
        Shimomura, Satoru; Higuchi, Masakazu; Matsuda, Ryotaro; Yoneda, Ko; Hijikata, Yuh; Kubota, Yoshiki; Mita, Yoshimi; Kim, Jungeun; Takata, Masaki; Kitagawa, Susumu
        Nature Chemistry (2010), 2 (8), 633-637CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Porous coordination polymers are materials formed from metal ions that are bridged together by org. linkers and that can combine two seemingly contradictory properties-crystallinity and flexibility. Porous coordination polymers can therefore create highly regular yet dynamic nanoporous domains that are particularly promising for sorption applications. Here, we describe the effective selective sorption of dioxygen and nitric oxide by a structurally and electronically dynamic porous coordination polymer built from zinc centers and tetracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQ) as a linker. In contrast to a variety of other gas mols. (C2H2, Ar, CO2, N2 and CO), O2 and NO are accommodated in its pores. This unprecedented preference arises from the concerted effect of the charge-transfer interaction between TCNQ and these guests, and the switchable gate opening and closing of the pores of the framework. This system provides further insight into the efficient recognition of small gas mols.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXpt1aksbc%253D&md5=8410db01a01c5c47d3276da6e4b1382d
      7. 7
        Wu, H.; Gong, Q.; Olson, D. H.; Li, J. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 836– 868
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7
        Commensurate Adsorption of Hydrocarbons and Alcohols in Microporous Metal Organic Frameworks
        Wu, Haohan; Gong, Qihan; Olson, David H.; Li, Jing
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 836-868CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Commensurate adsorption is an interesting and important phenomenon occurring during adsorption processes, where the mol. size and shape of the adsorbate (guest mol.) lead to an orientation and adsorbed amt. (at equil.) that is compatible and self-consistent with the crystal symmetry and pore structure of the adsorbent. As a new type of adsorbate material with distinctly advantageous features, microporous metal org. frameworks (MMOFs) demonstrate enormous potential for adsorption based applications, including storage, sepn., and purifn. of small gases and hydrocarbons. Commensurate adsorption of hydrocarbons occurs far more often in MMOFs than in zeolites and related materials, primarily as a result of a vastly greater variety of framework types and richer hierarchy of complexity of the pore structures for the former. Among numerous structures in which commensurate adsorption has been obsd. in the vicinity of room temp., many have 1D open channels built on pore segments of distinct shape, size, and narrow pore window that closely match with the geometries of hydrocarbon species.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XpsVOhtA%253D%253D&md5=5c1aad767ab767e289d672529b50f640
      8. 8
        Ferey, G.; Serre, C. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2009, 38, 1380– 1399
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8
        Large breathing effects in three-dimensional porous hybrid matter: facts, analyses, rules and consequences
        Ferey, Gerard; Serre, Christian
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1380-1399CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. This crit. review focuses on a strange behavior of crystd. solid matter: its reversible swelling with large magnitude. This will be of interest for experts in porous solids but also for solid state chemists and physicists. Some examples, classified according to the dimensionality of the inorg. subnetwork, present the general requirements and the structural rules which govern the existence of this phenomenon. Its consequences concern specific applications related to sensors, energy savings, sustainable development and health (100 refs.).

        Hysteretic Adsorption and Desorption of Hydrogen by Nanoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Zhao, Xuebo; Xiao, Bo; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark; Bradshaw, Darren; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2004), 306 (5698), 1012-1015CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Adsorption and desorption of hydrogen from nanoporous materials, such as activated C, is usually fully reversible. The authors prepd. nanoporous metal-org. framework materials with flexible linkers in which the pore openings, as characterized in the static structures, appear to be too small to allow H2 to pass. The authors observe hysteresis in their adsorption and desorption kinetics above the supercrit. temp. of H2 that reflects the dynamical opening of the windows between pores. This behavior would allow H2 to be adsorbed at high pressures but stored at lower pressures.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXptFyjtbc%253D&md5=42cbb6e1b708cd791929d4e89d328f95

        Zhang, J. P.; Lin, Y. Y.; Huang, X. C.; Chen, X. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127, 5495– 5506
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10
        Copper(I) 1,2,4-Triazolates and Related Complexes: Studies of the Solvothermal Ligand Reactions, Network Topologies, and Photoluminescence Properties
        Zhang, Jie-Peng; Lin, Yan-Yong; Huang, Xiao-Chun; Chen, Xiao-Ming
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (15), 5495-5506CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        One-pot solvothermal treatments of organonitriles, NH3, and CuII salts yielded CuI and 3,5-disubstituted 1,2,4-triazolates. The org. triazolate components were derived from Cu-mediated oxidative cycloaddn. of nitriles and NH3, in which a key intermediate 1,3,5-triazapentadienate was isolated as [CuII(4-pytap)2] (4-Hpytap = 2,4-di(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazapentadiene) via controlled solvothermal conditions. This intermediate could also be synthesized by NiII-mediated reactions; however, the final triazoles were obtained only when CuII was employed. Therefore, the reaction mechanism of these reactions was elucidated as follows: nitrile was 1st attacked by NH3 to form the amidine, which further reacted with another nitrile or self-condensed to yield 1,3,5-triazapentadiene, which was coordinated to two CuII ions in its deprotonated form. A two-electron oxidn. of the 1,3,5-triazapentadienate mediated by two CuII ions gave one triazolate and CuI cations. Other in situ ligand reactions, such as C-C bond cleavage and hydrolysis, were also found for the nitriles under these solvothermal conditions. Another remarkable feature of these cryst. CuI triazolates is their simple, typical 3- or 4-connected network topologies. The self-assembly of these nets is presumably controlled by steric hindrance, which is subsequently applied to the rational design of the close-packed 2-dimensional networks [CuI(tz)]∞ and [AgI(tz)]∞ (Htz = 1,2,4-triazole), as well as the porous 3-dimensional network [CuI(etz)]∞ (Hetz = 3,5-diethyl-1,2,4-triazole). The interesting photoluminescence properties of these coinage d10 metal complexes were also studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXis1ahsL8%253D&md5=91ebd3bb83c2b267c7fb38733aa634e8

        Ma, L. Q.; Abney, C.; Lin, W. B. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2009, 38, 1248– 1256
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Enantioselective catalysis with homochiral metal-organic frameworks
        Ma, Liqing; Abney, Carter; Lin, Wenbin
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1248-1256CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        This tutorial review presents recent developments of homochiral metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) for enantioselective catalysis. Following a brief introduction of the basic concepts and potential virtues of MOFs in catalysis, three distinct strategies that have been utilized to synthesize homochiral MOFs were summarized. Framework stability and accessibility of the open channels to reagents were then addressed. Some recent successful examples of catalytically active homochiral MOFs based on three approaches, namely, homochiral MOFs with achiral catalytic sites, incorporation of asym. catalysts directly into the framework, and post-synthetic modification of homochiral MOFs were finally surveyed. Although still in their infancy, homochiral MOFs have clearly demonstrated their utility in heterogeneous asym. catalysis, and a bright future is foreseen for the development of practically useful homochiral MOFs in the prodn. of optically pure org. mols.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkvVamu7Y%253D&md5=6ea10120922522f3f7fc76a6a04ea6cf

        Wang, C.; Wang, J.-L.; Lin, W. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 19895– 19908
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12
        Elucidating Molecular Iridium Water Oxidation Catalysts Using Metal-Organic Frameworks: A Comprehensive Structural, Catalytic, Spectroscopic, and Kinetic Study
        Wang, Cheng; Wang, Jin-Liang; Lin, Wenbin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (48), 19895-19908CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        As a new class of porous, cryst., mol. materials, metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have shown great promise as recyclable and reusable single-site solid catalysts. Periodic order and site isolation of the catalytic struts in MOFs facilitate the studies of their activities and reaction mechanisms. Herein we report the construction of two highly stable MOFs (1 and 2) using elongated dicarboxylate bridging ligands derived from Cp*Ir(L)Cl complexes (L = dibenzoate-substituted 2,2'-bipyridine, bpy-dc, or dibenzoate-substituted 2-phenylpyridine, ppy-dc) and Zr6O4(OH)4(carboxylate)12 cuboctahedral secondary building units (SBUs) and the elucidation of water oxidn. pathways of the Cp*Ir(L)Cl catalysts using these MOFs. We carried out detailed kinetic studies of Ce4+-driven water oxidn. reactions (WORs) catalyzed by the MOFs using UV-vis spectroscopy, phosphorescent oxygen detection, and gas chromatog. anal. These results confirmed not only water oxidn. activity of the MOFs but also indicated oxidative degrdn. of the Cp* rings during the WOR. The (bpy-dc)Ir(H2O)2XCl (X is likely a formate or acetate group) complex resulted from the oxidative degrdn. process was identified as a competent catalyst responsible for the water oxidn. activity of 1. Further characterization of the MOFs recovered from WORs using X-ray photoelectron, diffuse-reflectance UV-vis absorption, luminescence, and IR spectroscopies supported the identity of (bpy-dc)Ir(H2O)2XCl as an active water oxidn. catalyst. Kinetics of MOF-catalyzed WORs were monitored by Ce4+ consumptions and fitted with a reaction-diffusion model, revealing an intricate relationship between reaction and diffusion rates. Our work underscores the opportunity in using MOFs as well-defined single-site solid catalytic systems to reveal mechanistic details that are difficult to obtain for their homogeneous counterparts.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xhs1CksrzO&md5=b6d37724a49dc1a134fb87080c8c9d06

        Metal-organic framework materials as catalysts
        Lee, Jeong Yong; Farha, Omar K.; Roberts, John; Scheidt, Karl A.; Nguyen, Son Binh T.; Hupp, Joseph T.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1450-1459CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review; a crit. review of the emerging field of MOF-based catalysis is presented. Discussed are examples of: (a) opportunistic catalysis with metal nodes, (b) designed catalysis with framework nodes, (c) catalysis by homogeneous catalysts incorporated as framework struts, (d) catalysis by MOF-encapsulated mol. species, (e) catalysis by metal-free org. struts or cavity modifiers, and (f) catalysis by MOF-encapsulated clusters.

        14
        Size-Selective Lewis Acid Catalysis in a Microporous Metal-Organic Framework with Exposed Mn2+ Coordination Sites
        Horike, Satoshi; Dinca, Mircea; Tamaki, Kentaro; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (18), 5854-5855CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Treatment of selected aldehydes and ketones R1COR2 (R1 = Ph, R2 = H, Me; R1 = 4-PhC6H4, 4-PhOC6H4, 1-naphthyl, R2 = H) with Me3SiCN in the presence of the microporous metal-org. framework Mn3[(Mn4Cl)3BTT8(CH3OH)10]2 (I, H3BTT = 1,3,5-benzenetristetrazol-5-yl) leads to rapid conversion to the corresponding cyanosilylated products R1R2C(CN)OSiMe3. The transformation is catalyzed by coordinatively unsatd. Mn2+ ions that serve as Lewis acids and lead to conversion yields of 98 and 90% for benzaldehyde and 1-naphthaldehyde, the highest thus far for a metal-org. framework. Larger carbonyl substrates cannot diffuse through the pores of I, and conversion yields are much lower for these, attesting to the heterogeneity of the reaction and its dependence on guest size. The Mukaiyama-aldol reaction, known to require much more active Lewis catalysts, is also catalyzed in the presence of I, representing the first such example for a metal-org. framework. Conversion yields obtained for the reaction of benzaldehyde with silyl enolate Me2C:C(OMe)OSiMe3 reach 63%, on par with those obtained with zeolites. Size selectivity is demonstrated for the first time with this reaction through the use of larger silyl enolate substrates.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXksVeqs7w%253D&md5=4c04e2441b790417d12ba4fa084d9c10
      15. 15
        Xuan, W. M.; Zhu, C. F.; Liu, Y.; Cui, Y. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2012, 41, 1677– 1695
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15
        Mesoporous metal-organic framework materials
        Xuan, Weimin; Zhu, Chengfeng; Liu, Yan; Cui, Yong
        Chemical Society Reviews (2012), 41 (5), 1677-1695CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a new type of porous materials for diverse applications. Most open MOFs reported to date are microporous (pore sizes <2 nm), and only a small fraction of MOFs with ordered mesoscale domains (2-50 nm) is reported. This tutorial review covers recent advances in the field of mesoporous MOFs (mesoMOFs), including their design and synthesis, porosity activation and surface modification, and potential applications in storage and sepn., catalysis, drug delivery and imaging. Their specificities are dependent on the pore shape, size, and chem. environments of the cages or channels. The relationship between the structures and functions is discussed. The future outlook for the field is discussed in the context of current challenges in applications of mesoporous materials.

        Wang, C.; Lin, W. B. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133, 4232– 4235
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17
        Diffusion-Controlled Luminescence Quenching in Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Wang, Cheng; Lin, Wenbin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (12), 4232-4235CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Diffusion-controlled luminescence quenching of a phosphorescent metal-org. framework built from the Ru(bpy)32+-derived bridging ligand (MOF-1) was studied using a series of amines of different sizes as quenchers. The dynamics of amine diffusion into solvent-filled MOF-1 channels was probed by modeling time-dependent luminescence quenching data, which provide quant. diffusion coeffs. for the amine quenchers. Triethylamine, tripropylamine, and tributylamine were found to follow Fickian diffusion with a diffusivity of (1.1 ± 0.2) × 10-13, (4.8 ± 1.2) × 10-14, and (4.0 ± 0.4) × 10-14 m2/s, resp. Diisopropylethylamine (DIPEA), on the other hand, was found to be too large to enter the MOF channels. Despite its size, 4-MeOPhNPh2 can enter the MOF channels via a slow, complicated framework/guest intercalation process to result in extensive framework distortion as revealed by powder x-ray diffraction. This work represents the first quant. study of the dynamics of mol. diffusion into solvent-filled MOF channels. Such quant. information on mol. diffusion in MOFs is of fundamental importance to many of their potential applications (e.g., heterogeneous catalysis).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXivFyhtbw%253D&md5=e7841f23f2a3d50ac5948ae1b7f000ab
      18. 18
        Bauer, C. A.; Timofeeva, T. V.; Setterstten, T. B.; Patterson, B. D.; Liu, V. B.; Simmons, B. A.; Allendorf, M. D. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007, 129, 7136– 7144
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        18
        Influence of Connectivity and Porosity on Ligand-Based Luminescence in Zinc Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Bauer, Christina A.; Timofeeva, Tatiana V.; Settersten, Thomas B.; Patterson, Brian D.; Liu, Vincent H.; Simmons, Blake A.; Allendorf, Mark D.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (22), 7136-7144CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Applications of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) require close correlation between their structure and function. The authors describe the prepn. and characterization of two Zn MOFs based on a flexible and emissive linker mol., stilbene, which retains its luminescence within these solid materials. Reaction of trans-4,4'-stilbenedicarboxylic acid (H2L) and zinc nitrate in DMF yielded a dense 2-dimensional network, Zn3L3(DMF)2 (1), featuring Zn in both octahedral and tetrahedral coordination environments connected by trans-stilbene links. Similar reaction in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) at higher temps., followed by replacement of solvent in workup, resulted in a porous, 3-dimensional framework structure, Zn4OL3·(DMF)(CHCl3) (2). This framework consists of two interpenetrating cubic lattices, each featuring basic Zn carboxylate vertexes joined by trans-stilbene, analogous to the isoreticular MOF (IRMOF) series. The optical properties of both 1 and 2 correlate with the local ligand environments obsd. in the crystal structures. Steady-state and time-resolved spectroscopic measurements reveal that the stilbene linkers in the dense structure 1 exhibit a small degree of interchromophore coupling. In contrast, the stilbenoid units in 2 display very little interaction in this low-d. 3-dimensional framework, with excitation and emission spectra characteristic of monomeric stilbenes, similar to the dicarboxylic acid in dil. soln. In both cases, the rigidity of the stilbene linker increases upon coordination to the inorg. units through inhibition of torsion about the central ethylene bond, resulting in luminescent crystals with increased emission lifetimes compared to solns. of trans-stilbene. The emission spectrum of 2 depends on the nature of the incorporated solvent mols., suggesting use of this or related materials in sensor applications.

        A luminescent microporous metal-organic framework for the fast and reversible detection of high explosives
        Lan, Anjian; Li, Kunhao; Wu, Haohan; Olson, David H.; Emge, Thomas J.; Ki, Woosoek; Hong, Maochun; Li, Jing
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2009), 48 (13), 2334-2338CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A highly luminescent microporous metal-org. framework, [Zn2(bpdc)2(bpee)] (bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate; bpee = 1,2-bipyridylethene), was prepd., characterized by X-ray crystallog., and found to be capable of very fast and reversible detection of the vapors of the nitroarom. explosive 2,4-dinitrotoluene and the plastic explosive taggant 2,3-dimethyl-2,3-dinitrobutane through redox fluorescence quenching with unprecedented sensitivity.
