        Solvatochromic Behavior of a Nanotubular Metal-Organic Framework for Sensing Small Molecules
        Lu, Zhen-Zhong; Zhang, Rui; Li, Yi-Zhi; Guo, Zi-Jian; Zheng, He-Gen
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (12), 4172-4174CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A nanotubular metal-org. framework (MOF), {[(WS4Cu4)I2(dptz)3]·DMF}n (dptz = 3,6-di(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine, DMF = DMF) for sensing small solvent mols. is presented. When accommodating different solvent mols. as guests, the resulting inclusion compds. exhibit different colors depending on the solvent guests, and more interestingly, the band gaps of these solvent-included complexes are in linear correlation with the polarity of the guest solvents. The solvent mols. can be sensed by the changes of UV-visible spectra of the corresponding inclusion compds., showing a new way of signal transduction as a new kind of sensor. The sensing by such a MOF occurs within the channel-contg. material rather than on the external surface.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXislGntbk%253D&md5=039fac5f14b14b2f4199d5ed2fb15612
      21. 21
        Chen, B.; Xiang, S.; Qian, G. Acc. Chem. Res. 2010, 43, 1115– 1124
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        21
        Metal-Organic Frameworks with Functional Pores for Recognition of Small Molecules
        Chen, Banglin; Xiang, Shengchang; Qian, Guodong
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2010), 43 (8), 1115-1124CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Mol. recognition, an important process in biol. and chem. systems, governs the diverse functions of a variety of enzymes and unique properties of some synthetic receptors. Because mol. recognition is based on weak interactions between receptors and substrates, the design and assembly of synthetic receptors to mimic biol. systems and the development of novel materials to discriminate different substrates for selective recognition of specific mols. has proved challenging. The extensive research on synthetic receptors for mol. recognition, particularly on noncovalent complexes self-assembled by hydrogen bonding and metal-org. coordination, has revealed some underlying principles. In particular, these studies have demonstrated that the shapes of the supramol. receptors play significant roles in their specific and selective recognition of substrates: receptors can offer concave surfaces that complement their convex targets. This Account describes our research to develop a synthetic mol. recognition platform using porous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). These materials contain functional pores to direct their specific and unique recognition of small mols. through several types of interactions: van der Waals interactions of the framework surface with the substrate, metal-substrate interactions, and hydrogen bonding of the framework surface with the substrate. These materials have potential applications for gas storage, sepn., and sensing. We demonstrate a simple strategy to construct a primitive cubic net of interpenetrated microporous MOFs from the self-assembly of the paddle-wheel clusters M2(CO2)4 (M = Cu2+, Zn2+, and Co2+) with two types of org. dicarboxylic acid and pillar bidentate linkers. This efficient method allows us to rationally tune the micropores to size-exclusively sort different small gas mols., leading to the highly selective sepn. and purifn. of gases. By optimizing the strong interactions between open metal sites within porous MOFs and gas mols. such as hydrogen and acetylene, we have developed several MOF materials with extraordinary acetylene storage capacity at room temp. We have also immobilized Lewis acidic and basic sites into luminescent porous MOFs to recognize and sense neutral and ionic species. Using the strategy to systematically immobilize different open metal sites within porous MOFs from the metallo-ligand precursors, we have developed the first microporous mixed-metal-org. framework (M'MOF) with enhanced affinity for hydrogen mols., which successfully sepd. D2 from H2 using kinetic isotope quantum mol. sieving. Because we can functionalize the pores to direct their specific recognition of small mols., the emerging porous MOFs serve as novel functional materials for gas storage, sepn., heterogeneous catalysis, and sensing.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXlslyhtrs%253D&md5=f9230905a5656f9fe0e487967ecae356
      22. 22
        Gu, Z. Y.; Yan, X. P. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2010, 49, 1477– 1480
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        22
        Metal-organic framework MIL-101 for high-resolution gas-chromatographic separation of xylene isomers and ethylbenzene
        Gu, Zhi-Yuan; Yan, Xiu-Ping
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2010), 49 (8), 1477-1480, S1477/1-S1477/6CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        MIL-101 is a chromium terephthalate MOF with coordinatively unsatd. sites (CUS). The authors utilized MIL-101 as the stationary phase because of its high surface area, large pores (2.9-3.4 nm), accessible CUS, and excellent chem. and thermal stability, which make it an attractive candidate for isomer sepn. In this work, the authors prepd. the MIL-101 coated capillary column and achieved a baseline sepn. of p-xylene, o-xylene, m-xylene, and ethylbenzene on the fabricated MOF coated capillary column by GC within 1.6 min without the need for temp. programming.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXitVWjsb0%253D&md5=7d7ad0f5b8a9a3335e2ee0ab04a6020c
      23. 23
        Liu, D.; Lang, J.-P.; Abrahams, B. F. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133, 11042– 11045

        Highly Efficient Separation of a Solid Mixture of Naphthalene and Anthracene by a Reusable Porous Metal-Organic Framework through a Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal Transformation
        Liu, Dong; Lang, Jian-Ping; Abrahams, Brendan F.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (29), 11042-11045CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The three-dimensional cryst. porous metal-org. framework [Ni2(μ2-OH2)(1,3-BDC)2(tpcb)]n (1) [1,3-H2BDC = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid; tpcb = tetrakis(4-pyridyl)cyclobutane] was used to sep. a solid mixt. of naphthalene and anthracene at room temp. via selective adsorption of naphthalene. The process involved a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation. The guest naphthalene mols. could be exchanged with ethanol, and the host, 1, could be regenerated by removal of the guest ethanol mols.

        MnII-based MIL-53 Analogues: Synthesis Using Neutral Bridging μ2-Ligands and Application in Liquid-Phase Adsorption and Separation of C6-C8 Aromatics
        Xu, Guohai; Zhang, Xiaoguang; Guo, Peng; Pan, Chengling; Zhang, Hongjie; Wang, Cheng
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (11), 3656-3657CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Four MnII-based MIL-53 single crystals were prepd. using four neutral pyridine N-oxides as bridging μ2-ligands. In the case of 4,4'-bipyridine-N,N'-dioxide (BPNO), the infinite Mn oxide chains were further interconnected by BPNO besides BDC, which allows 1-dimensional channels to be accessible for guest mols. The liq.-phase adsorption and sepn. of C6-C8 aroms. using the evacuated compd. as an absorbent were studied via crystal-to-crystal transformations. Both structural evolution of the compds. and selectivity of C6-C7 aroms. of one evacuated compd. could be attributed to noncovalent interactions, esp. π-π interaction.

        Zn2[(S)-O3PCH2NHC4H7CO2]2: A homochiral 3D zinc phosphonate with helical channels
        Shi, Xin; Zhu, Guangshan; Qiu, Shilun; Huang, Kunlin; Yu, Jihong; Xu, Ruren
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (47), 6482-6485CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The prepn. and crystal structure of a homochiral 3D zinc phosphonate, Zn2[(S)-O3PCH2NHC4H7CO2]2, with helical channels is reported. Three types of channels, right-handed (R) and left-handed (L) helical and achiral (A), alternate along the c axis in the structure of the title compd. The catalytically active groups of the 1-phosphonomethylproline ligands are directed into the channels, thus suggesting applications of this material in asym. catalysis.

        QMOF-1 and QMOF-2: three-dimensional metal-organic open frameworks with a quartz-like topology
        Sun, Jinyu; Weng, Linhong; Zhou, Yaming; Chen, Jinxi; Chen, Zhenxia; Liu, Zhicheng; Zhao, Dongyuan
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (23), 4471-4473CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The synthesis of two α- and β-quartz structures with open metal-org. frameworks (QMOF-1 and QMOF-2) is reported. QMOF-1 is assigned to Zn(ISN)2·2 H2O (ISN = isonicotinic acid) with the low symmetry of α-quartz, while QMOF-2 to InH(BDC)2 (BDC = terephthalate) with the high symmetry of β-quartz.

        Single- and Double-Layer Structures and Sorption Properties of Two Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks with Flexible Tritopic Ligand
        Han, Liqin; Yan, Yan; Sun, Fuxing; Cai, Kun; Borjigin, Tsolmon; Zhao, Xiaojun; Qu, Fengyu; Zhu, Guangshan
        Crystal Growth & Design (2013), 13 (4), 1458-1463CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Two 2-dimensional multifunctional microporous metal-org. frameworks, [Cd3(L)2(H2O)6]·1.5H2O·2EtOH·DMF (1, H3L = 2,4,6-tris-(4-carboxyphenoxy)-1,3,5-triazine) and [Zn3(L)2(H2O)2]·3H2O·TEA·2DMF (2), with single- and double-(6,3)-layer structures, resp., were synthesized by the reaction of Cd(Zn) nitrate with H3L in a mixed solvent of DMF, EtOH, and H2O. TGA and PXRD anal. showed that 1 and 2 were thermally stable up to 250°. Gas sorption measurement indicates that these compds. exhibited selective sorption capabilities for CO2 over CH4 and N2 and could adsorb considerable amts. of H2 at low temp. 1 And 2 also showed high sorption capabilities for H2O, MeOH, and EtOH vapors. The highest adsorption amts. of compds. 1 and 2 are 168.8 and 257.3 cc/g for H2O, 175.1 and 140.8 cc/g for MeOH, and 91.7 and 76.2 cc/g for EtOH, resp. Also, the max. luminescence emission peaks of 1 and 2 exhibit blue shifts of 138 and 132 nm, resp., compared to the free ligand.

        The current status of hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
        Zhao, Dan; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Energy & Environmental Science (2008), 1 (2), 222-235CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. The theor. and exptl. hydrogen storage studies on metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have been reviewed. Seven distinct factors influencing hydrogen uptake capacity in MOFs have been classified and discussed. Based on existing studies, some possible future developments have been proposed.

        Modular Chemistry: Secondary Building Units as a Basis for the Design of Highly Porous and Robust Metal-Organic Carboxylate Frameworks
        Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Moler, David B.; Li, Hailian; Chen, Banglin; Reineke, Theresa M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2001), 34 (4), 319-330CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review, with 38 refs. Secondary building units (SBUs) are mol. complexes and cluster entities in which ligand coordination modes and metal coordination environments can be used in the transformation of these fragments into extended porous networks using polytopic linkers (1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5,7-adamantanetetracarboxylate, etc.). Consideration of the geometric and chem. attributes of the SBUs and linkers leads to prediction of the framework topol., and in turn to the design and synthesis of a new class of porous materials with robust structures and high porosity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXhtFymsL0%253D&md5=e3df2f7492090aee280676f044e3b7af

        Tranchemontagne, D. J.; Mendoza-Cortés, J. L.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2009, 38, 1257– 1283
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30
        Secondary building units, nets and bonding in the chemistry of metal-organic frameworks
        Tranchemontagne, David J.; Mendoza-Cortes, Jose L.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1257-1283CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        This crit. review presents a comprehensive study of transition-metal carboxylate clusters which may serve as secondary building units (SBUs) towards construction and synthesis of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). We describe the geometries of 131 SBUs, their connectivity and compn. This contribution presents a comprehensive list of the wide variety of transition-metal carboxylate clusters which may serve as secondary building units (SBUs) in the construction and synthesis of metal-org. frameworks. The SBUs discussed here were obtained from a search of mols. and extended structures archived in the Cambridge Structure Database (CSD, version 5.28, Jan. 2007) which included only crystals contg. metal carboxylate linkages (241 refs.).
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        31
        Reticular synthesis and the design of new materials
        Yaghi, Omar M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Chae, Hee K.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2003), 423 (6941), 705-714CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. The long-standing challenge of designing and constructing new cryst. solid-state materials from mol. building blocks is just beginning to be addressed with success. A conceptual approach that requires the use of secondary building units to direct the assembly of ordered frameworks epitomizes this process: the authors call this approach reticular synthesis. This chem. has yielded materials designed to have predetd. structures, compns. and properties. In particular, highly porous frameworks held together by strong metal-O-C bonds and with exceptionally large surface area and capacity for gas storage were prepd. and their pore metrics systematically varied and functionalized.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXksV2itro%253D&md5=2417c5adb0e948350d3d62350c8cd7ea
      32. 32
        Kim, J.; Chen, B. L.; Reineke, T. M.; Li, H.; Eddaoudi, M.; Moler, D. B.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2001, 123, 8239– 8247
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        32
        Assembly of Metal-Organic Frameworks from Large Organic and Inorganic Secondary Building Units: New Examples and Simplifying Principles for Complex Structures
        Kim, Jaheon; Chen, Banglin; Reineke, Theresa M.; Li, Hailian; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Moler, David B.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2001), 123 (34), 8239-8247CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The secondary building unit (SBU) was identified as a useful tool in the anal. of complex metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). The authors illustrate its applicability to rationalizing MOF crystal structures by anal. of nine new MOFs which were characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Tetrahedral SBUs in Zn(ADC)2·(HTEA)2 (MOF-31; H2ADC = acetylenedicarboxylic acid; HTEA = monoprotonated triethylamine), Cd(ATC)·[Cd(H2O)6](H2O)5 (MOF-32; H4ATC = adamantanetetracarboxylic acid), and Zn2(ATB)(H2O)·(H2O)3(DMF)3 (MOF-33; H4ATB = adamantanetetrabenzoic acid) are linked into diamond networks, while those of Ni2(ATC)(H2O)4·(H2O)4 (MOF-34) have the structure of the Al network in SrAl2. Frameworks constructed from less sym. tetrahedral SBUs have the Ga network of CaGa2O4 as illustrated by Zn2(ATC)·(EtOH)2(H2O)2 (MOF-35) structure. Squares and tetrahedral SBUs in Zn2(MTB)(H2O)2·(DMF)6(H2O)5 (MOF-36; H4MTB = methanetetrabenzoic acid) are linked into the PtS network, which is the simplest structure type known for the assembly of these shapes. The octahedral SBUs found in Zn2(NDC)3·[(HTEA)(DEF)(ClBz)]2 (MOF-37; H2NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid) form the most common structure for linking octahedral shapes, namely, the B network in CaB6. New structure types for linking triangular and trigonal prismatic SBUs are found in Zn3O(BTC)2·(HTEA)2 (MOF-38; H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) and Zn3O(HBTB)2(H2O)·(DMF)0.5(H2O)3 (MOF-39; H3BTB = 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoic acid). The synthesis, crystal structure, and structure anal. using the SBU approach are presented for each MOF.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXls1Okt7w%253D&md5=b62be98fb09b7b7995390315da27c217

        Chae, H. K.; Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J.; Hauck, S. I.; Hartwing, J. F.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2001, 123, 11482– 11483
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33
        Tertiary Building Units: Synthesis, Structure, and Porosity of a Metal-Organic Dendrimer Framework (MODF-1)
        Chae, Hee K.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; Hauck, Sheila I.; Hartwig, John F.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2001), 123 (46), 11482-11483CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A cryst. metalorg. dendrimer framework (MODF-1) of compn. Zn4O(TTA)(DMA)2·(DMA)3(H2O)21 (DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide), where zinc ions link the carboxy terminated triarylamine dendrimer 4,4',4''-tris[N,N-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)amino]triphenylamine (H6TTA), was prepd. The carboxy-terminated, first-generation dendrimer with triarylamine branches and a triarylamine core was prepd. by Pd-catalyzed amination. The H6TTA linker contg. six peripheral carboxy groups to coordinate metal ions was prepd. by coupling of 4,4',4''-tribromotriphenylamine with 4,4'-di-tert-butoxycarbonyl-diphenylamine and subsequent thermal conversion of the tert-Bu carboxylates to the free acids. The crystal structure of MODF-1 shows a 3-D porous framework that is created by linking the branched org. unit with Zn(II) ions at each of the six carboxylate termini. Upon heating from 20-700°, MODF-1 lost wt. immediately; a sharp decrease in mol. wt. was obsd. at 50°, and this decrease continued slowly up to 300°. The total mass loss was 28.3%, which corresponds to dissocn. of two DMA ligands and the three DMA and five H2O guests in each formula unit; a further decrease in wt., 53.3%, occurred between 400 and 600°, corresponding to loss of the TTA unit (55%) and decompn. of the material. Gas sorption isotherms of MODF-1 evacuated at 5 × 10-5 Torr and 25° for 20 h in a microbalance for gases or vapors of N2, Ar, CH2Cl2, CCl4, C6H6, and C6H12 showed type-I sorption behavior, indicating that evacuated MODF-1 has permanent porosity, similar to that of zeolites and porous MOFs. The isotherms of MODF-1 are reversible and show no hysteresis upon desorption of sorbates from the pores. A pore vol. of 0.26 cm 3/g and an estd. surface area of 740 m 2/g were calcd. from the N2 isotherm.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXnslOhsb4%253D&md5=dc19f151c26950671df7bc36eb78e9a8
      34. 34
        Fang, Q.-R.; Zhu, G.-S.; Xue, M.; Zhang, Q.-L.; Sun, J.-Y.; Guo, X.-D.; Qiu, S.-L.; Xu, S.-T.; Wang, P.; Wang, D.-J.; Wei, Y. Chem.—Eur. J. 2006, 12, 3754– 3758
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Microporous metal-organic framework constructed from heptanuclear zinc carboxylate secondary building units
        Fang, Qian-Rong; Zhu, Guang-Shan; Xue, Ming; Zhang, Qing-Lin; Sun, Jin-Yu; Guo, Xiao-Dan; Qiu, Shi-Lun; Xu, Shi-Tao; Wang, Ping; Wang, De-Jun; Wei, Yen
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2006), 12 (14), 3754-3758CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A novel, three-dimensional, noninterpenetrating microporous metal-org. framework (MOF), [Zn7O2(pda)5(H2O)2]·5DMF·4EtOH·6H2O (1, H2PDA = p-phenylenediacrylic acid), was synthesized by constructing heptanuclear zinc carboxylate secondary building units (SBUs) and by using rigid and linear arom. carboxylate ligands, PDA. The x-ray crystallog. data reveals that the seven zinc centers of 1 are held together with ten carboxylate groups of the PDA ligands and four water mols. to form a heptametallic SBU, Zn7O4(CO2)10, with dimensions of 9.8 × 9.8 × 13.8 Å3. Also, the heptametallic SBUs are interconnected by PDA acting as linkers, thereby generating an extended network with a three-dimensional, noninterpenetrating, intersecting large-channel system with spacing of ∼17.3 Å. As a microporous framework, polymer 1 shows adsorption behavior that is favorable towards H2O and CH3OH, and substantial H2 uptake. In terms of the heptanuclear zinc carboxylate SBUs, polymer 1 exhibits interesting photoelectronic properties, which would facilitate the exploration of new types of semiconducting materials, esp. among MOFs contg. multinuclear metal carboxylate SBUs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XkvFKltbc%253D&md5=6122e5ceff9f6465942e244c4d68d71f

        Sorption behaviour in a unique 3,12-connected zinc-organic framework with 2.4 nm cages
        Qian, Jinjie; Jiang, Feilong; Su, Kongzhao; Pan, Jie; Zhang, Linjie; Li, Xingjun; Yuan, Daqiang; Hong, Maochun
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2013), 1 (36), 10631-10634CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Crystals of zinc-org. framework [Zn9(BTB)4(odabco)3(μ3-O)3(μ2-H2O)6]·16DEF (FJI-2) (H3BTB = 1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene; odabco = N-oxide-1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane; DEF = N,N-diethylformamide) were obtained by solvothermal reaction of Zn(NO3)3·6H2O, H3BTB and dabco in DEF:HBF4:water mixt. at 85° for 4 days. Single crystal x-ray crystallog. reveals FJI-2 structure to consist of rare hexanuclear zinc clusters forming 2.4 nm double-walled octahedral cages featuring a new 3,12-connected topol. FJI-2 has a good H2 uptake capacity of 149.7 cm3 g-1 (1.34%) at 77 K and 1.0 bar, and the IAST (ideal adsorbed soln. theory) calcn. predicts highly selective adsorption of CO2 over N2 and CH4.

        Zheng, S.-T.; Zhao, X.; Lau, S.; Fuhr, A.; Feng, P.; Bu, X. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2013, 135, 10270– 10273
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        36
        Entrapment of Metal Clusters in Metal-Organic Framework Channels by Extended Hooks Anchored at Open Metal Sites
        Zheng, Shou-Tian; Zhao, Xiang; Lau, Samuel; Fuhr, Addis; Feng, Pingyun; Bu, Xianhui
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (28), 10270-10273CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Open metal sites (OMSs) of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have been used for architectural pore design. OMSs were used to run extended hooks (isonicotinates in this work) from the framework walls to the channel centers to effect the capture of single metal ions or clusters, with the concurrent partitioning of the large channel spaces into multiple domains, alteration of the host-guest charge relationship and assocd. guest-exchange properties, and transfer of OMSs from the walls to the channel centers. The concept of the extended hook, demonstrated here in the multicomponent dual-metal and dual-ligand system, should be generally applicable to a range of framework types.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtVKitrbM&md5=f000e33c1410832d3a0e87d24dcc31fe

        Zheng, S.-T.; Wu, T.; Chou, C.; Fuhr, A.; Feng, P.; Bu, X. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 4517– 4520
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37
        Development of Composite Inorganic Building Blocks for MOFs
        Zheng, Shou-Tian; Wu, Tao; Chou, Chengtsung; Fuhr, Addis; Feng, Pingyun; Bu, Xianhui
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (10), 4517-4520CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A general direction for diversifying metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) is demonstrated by the synthesis of composite inorg. clusters between In and s-, d-, and f-block elements. Five series of MOFs, CPM-18-M (Me2NH2)[In3M(OH)4(BTC)3(DMF)3] (M = Nd,Sm), CPM-19-M [In3M2O(OH)3(BTB)3(H2O)6]·NO3 (M = Nd, Pr), CPM-20 [InCo2(OH)(INA)3(1,4-BDC)3/2], CPM-21-M [In2M2(OH)2(BTB)8/3(DMA)2] (M = Mn, Co, Cu), and CPM-23 [In2Mg2(OH)2(BTB)8/3(H2O)4], (H3BTC = trimesic acid, H3BTC = 1,3,5-tri(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene, HINA = isonicotinic acid, H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) are prepd. and characterized by crystal structure anal. These previously unknown indium heterometallic clusters, with various nuclearity, geometry, charge, and metal-to-metal ratios, significantly expand the pool of inorg. building blocks that are highly effective for the construction of porous MOFs with desolvated CPM-19-Nd and CPM-20 demonstrating high H2 and CO2 gas adsorption capacity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XivVOgsL0%253D&md5=37da41a2aa77275023e53bd8aa6ed8db

        Li, S.-L.; Xu, Q. Energy Environ. Sci. 2013, 6, 1656– 1683

        Metal-organic frameworks as platforms for clean energy
        Li, Shun-Li; Xu, Qiang
        Energy & Environmental Science (2013), 6 (6), 1656-1683CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. In order to void environmental pollution and an energy shortage, the application of clean and renewable energy, such as solar, instead of fossil fuel is foreseen as a prospective issue. It is urgent and important to develop and optimize various energy storage and conversion technologies and materials aimed at utilization of different clean energy sources. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), a new class of porous cryst. materials, act as an outstanding candidate in this field based on their high surface areas, controllable structures and excellent electrochem. properties. Here, selected recent and significant advances in the development of MOFs for clean energy applications are reviewed, and special emphases are shown to the applications of MOFs as platforms for hydrogen prodn. and storage, fuel cells, Li-ion rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors and solar cells.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXnvFyrs74%253D&md5=34abdbaddefe225d3f70a1b7cf6e806c
      39. 39
        Gong, Y.-N.; Meng, M.; Zhong, D.-C.; Huang, Y.-L.; Jiang, L.; Lu, T.-B. Chem. Commun. 2012, 48, 12002– 12004
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Counter-cation modulation of hydrogen and methane storage in a sodalite-type porous metal-organic framework

        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (98), 12002-12004CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A μ4-Cl bridged anionic sodalite-type porous metal-org. framework (Et2NH2)3[(Cu4Cl)3(TTCA)8]·26DEF was synthesized, in which Et2NH2+ can be exchanged by Li+ cations. The results of gas measurements indicate that Et2NH2+ and Li+ are beneficial for methane and hydrogen storage, resp.

        Fast detection of oxygen by the naked eye using a stable metal-organic framework containing methyl viologen cations
        Gong, Yun-Nan; Lu, Tong-Bu
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2013), 49 (70), 7711-7713CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A stable porous metal-org. framework (MOF) contg. Me viologen cations exhibits reversible photochromic, thermochromic and fluorescence changes via host-guest interactions, and can be used for fast and selective detection of oxygen by naked eye recognition of color change within five seconds.

        Constructions of two polycatenanes and one polypseudo-rotaxane by discrete tetrahedral cages and stool-like building units
        Jiang, Long; Ju, Ping; Meng, Xian-Rui; Kuang, Xiao-Jun; Lu, Tong-Bu
        Scientific Reports (2012), 2 (), 668/1-668/5, 5 pp.CODEN: SRCEC3; ISSN:2045-2322. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Mech. interlocked mols., such as catenanes and rotaxanes, are of great interest due to their fascinating structures and potential applications, while such mols. were mainly restricted to comprising components of interlocked rings or polygons. The constructions of infinite polycatenanes and polyrotaxanes by discrete cages remain great challenge and only two infinite polycatenanes fabricated by discrete cages are reported so far, while the structures of polyrotaxanes and polypseudo-rotaxanes fabricated by discrete build units were not documented to date. Herein the authors report the first example of a two-dimensional (2D) polypseudo-rotaxane {[NiL]5(tcba)3(PF6)(H2O)2} [2; L = 1,3-bis(2-aminoethyl)-1,3-propanediamine, H3tcba = tris(4-carboxybenzyl)amine] fabricated by stool-like build units, the second example of a 1-dimensional (1D) polycatenane {[NiL]4(Htcba)4(H2O)2} (1) and the second example of a three-dimensional (3D) polycatenane {H[NiL]6(tcba)4(ClO4)} (3), which were assembled by discrete tetrahedral cages. The pores of dehydrated 3-dimensional polycatenane are dynamic and display size-dependent adsorption/desorption behaviors of alcs.

        The porous metal-org. framework (MOF) PCM-4, based on tris(para-carboxylated) triphenylphosphine oxide, contains atypical, polar org. substituents; the material exhibits a hysteretic sorption of Ar, N2 and O2, and demonstrates the advantage of ligands of this type.

        Microporous Lanthanide-Organic Frameworks with Open Metal Sites: Unexpected Sorption Propensity and Multifunctional Properties
        Lee, Woo Ram; Ryu, Dae Won; Lee, Jin Wuk; Yoon, Jung Hee; Koh, Eui Kwan; Hong, Chang Seop
        Inorganic Chemistry (2010), 49 (11), 4723-4725CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Isostructural lanthanide-org. frameworks {[Ln(TPO)(DMF)]·(DMF)(H2O)n, Ln = Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd; n = 1.5 or 2} were prepd. by a solvothermal reaction of the corresponding metal ions and the phosphine-oxide-based tricarboxylate ligand (tris(4-carboxyphenyl)phosphine oxide = TPO). The gravimetric gas uptake of the desolvated compds. was unexpectedly increased when going from Nd3+ to Gd3+, which is assocd. with the enhanced surface areas and electrostatic interactions between exposed metal ions and gas mols. with quadrupole moments.

        High capacity CO2 adsorption in a Mg(II)-based phosphine oxide coordination material
        Bohnsack, Alisha M.; Ibarra, Ilich A.; Hatfield, Peter W.; Yoon, Ji-Woong; Hwang, Young-Kyu; Chang, Jong-San; Humphrey, Simon M.
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2011), 47 (17), 4899-4901CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The new porous phosphine coordination material, [Mg4(μ3-OH)2(tctpo)2(OH2)4] (PCM-11), is an unusual 8,4-connected coordination polymer with an open 3-dimensional pore structure, formed by reaction of Mg(II) with tris(p-carboxyphenyl)phosphine oxide (H3tctpo). The highly ionic nature of the metal-ligand bonding results in excellent thermal stability upon desolvation (>460°). PCM-11 is easily activated for small mol. sorption at low temp. without the requirement for solvent pre-exchange. It adsorbs 47.5% CO2 at 11.6 bar and 30°.

        Microwave-Assisted Synthesis of a Series of Lanthanide Metal-Organic Frameworks and Gas Sorption Properties
        Lin, Zu-Jin; Yang, Zhen; Liu, Tian-Fu; Huang, Yuan-Biao; Cao, Rong
        Inorganic Chemistry (2012), 51 (3), 1813-1820CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Isostructural microporous lanthanide metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) formulated as [Ln2(TPO)2(HCOO)]·(Me2NH2)·(DMF)4·(H2O)6 {Ln = Y (1), Sm (2), Eu (3), Gd (4), Tb (5), Dy (6), Ho (7), Er (8), Tm (9), Yb (10), and Lu (11); H3TPO = tris-(4-carboxylphenyl)phosphine oxide; DMF = DMF} was synthesized under microwave-assisted solvothermal reaction for 30 min. Alternatively, if a conventional solvothermal reaction is carried out under the same temp., a much longer time (3 days) is needed for the same phase in similar yield. Structure anal. reveals that the framework is a 4,8-connected network with point symbol (410·616·82) (45·6)2, which is the subnet of alb net. Thermal gravimetric analyses performed on as-synthesized MOFs reveal that the frameworks have high thermal stability. The luminescent properties of 2, 3, 5, and 6 were studied and show characteristic emissions for Sm(III), Eu(III), Tb(III), and Dy(III) at room temp., resp. Gas sorption properties of desolvated 1 and 3 were studied by exptl. measuring N, Ar, CO2, methane, and H sorption isotherms. The resulting materials show high and preferential CO2 adsorption over N2 gas at ambient temp., indicating that the present materials can be applied in a CO2 capture process.

The framework stability and crystal transformation are affected by the charges of foreign cations.

        Ibarra, I. A.; Yoon, J. W.; Chang, J.-S.; Lee, S. K.; Lynch, V. M.; Humphrey, S. M. Inorg. Chem. 2012, 51, 12242– 12247

        47
        Organic Vapor Sorption in a High Surface Area Dysprosium(III)-Phosphine Oxide Coordination Material
        Ibarra, Ilich A.; Yoon, Ji Woong; Chang, Jong-San; Lee, Su Kyoung; Lynch, Vincent M.; Humphrey, Simon M.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2012), 51 (22), 12242-12247CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        PCM-16 is a phosphine coordination material comprised of Dy(III) and triphenylphosphine oxide, which displays the highest reported CO2 BET surface area for a Ln(III) coordination polymer of 1511 m2 g-1. PCM-16 also adsorbs 2.7% H2 and 65.1% O2 at 77 K and 0.97 bar. The adsorption-desorption behavior of org. vapors were studied in PCM-16 to probe the nature of certain host-guest interactions in the pores. Arom. and polar guest species showed high uptakes and marked adsorption/desorption hysteresis, while aliph. vapors were less easily adsorbed. The surface area of PCM-16 could be increased significantly (to 1814 m2 g-1) via exchange of Me2NH2+ cations in the pores with smaller NH4+ groups.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhsF2ktb7M&md5=a57a019ff08ba39614f36d29da731486

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        48
        N-phenyl-P,P,P-triarylphospha-λ5-azenes, triarylphosphines, and triarylphosphine oxides. Substituent effects on nitrogen-15, phosphorus-31, and carbon-13 NMR spectra
        Chou, Whe Narn; Pomerantz, Martin
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (1991), 56 (8), 2762-9CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
        The syntheses and 15N, 31P, and 13C NMR spectra of a series of N-phenyl-P,P,P-triarylphospha-λ5-azenes (p-RC6H4)3P:NPh (I, R = H, Cl, NMe2, etc.) and the 31P and 13C NMR spectra of the corresponding series of triarylphosphines (p-RC6H4)3P (II) and triarylphosphine oxides (p-RC6H4)3PO (III) are reported. The substituent effects on the chem. shifts can be best accommodated and rationalized by use of a model for system I whereby the dipole of the aryl group and its pendant R group polarizes the rest of the mol. This includes the P and N atoms and Ph ring, where an electron-withdrawing R group increases the electron d. on the P, N, and ipso C-1 while decreasing the electron d. on C-3 and C-4 of the N-Ph ring. A similar polarization pattern for the phosphine oxide series III is suggested. In the phosphine series II, the chem. shift data is consistent with the lone electron pair on the phosphorus atom delocalizing into the aryl rings. The coupling const. data, in particular 1JPN for series I and 1JPC for series I-III, were examd. with use of the Hammett monosubstituent parameter and the Taft dual-substituent parameter approaches.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3MXhvVGlsLk%253D&md5=0e21e93996097c675b405ee96c9613cb

        Sheldrick, G. M. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. A 2008, 64, 112– 122
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        51
        A short history of SHELX
        Sheldrick, George M.
        Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
        An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsVGhurzO&md5=8f91f10be4a9df74b2a9dad522c71e6e
      52. 52

        Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON:

        Spek, A. L. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2003, 36, 7– 13
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        52
        Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
        Spek, A. L.
        Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
        The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlChtw%253D%253D&md5=0a85de2407551632bb287508534904e2
      53. 53
        Zhang, S.-Q.; Jiang, F.-L.; Wu, M.-Y.; Ma, J.; Bu, Y.; Hong, M.-C. Cryst. Growth Des. 2012, 12, 1452– 1463
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        53
        Assembly of Discrete One-, Two-, and Three-Dimensional Zn(II) Complexes Containing Semirigid V-Shaped Tricarboxylate Ligands
        Zhang, Shu-Quan; Jiang, Fei-Long; Wu, Ming-Yan; Ma, Jie; Bu, Yang; Hong, Mao-Chun
        Crystal Growth & Design (2012), 12 (3), 1452-1463CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Hydrothermal reaction of zinc nitrate, 4-(4-carboxyphenoxy)phthalic acid (H3cpop), and different N-donor coligands has afforded six novel supramol. compds., in which the nature of the neutral coligands plays a crucial structure-directing role. [Zn(Hcpop)(H2O)3]2 (1) and [Zn(Hcpop)(phen)(H2O)]2 (2, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) form three-dimensional (3D) supramol. frameworks linked by H-bonds and π-π interactions based on discrete mols. Similarly, [Zn2(Hcpop)2(4,4'-bpy)3(H2O)2]n·4nH2O (3) possesses a 3-dimensional supramol. structure, aggregated by interesting 1-dimensional (1D) armed-polyrotaxane chains. [Zn6(cpop)4(4,4'-bpy)2(H2O)2]n (4, 4,4'-bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine) exhibits a complicated 3-dimensional framework which can be rationalized as a (3,6,6)-connected trinodal net with a unique (4.62)2(42.69.83.10)(44.68.83) topol. [Zn3(cpop)2(bpdb)(H2O)2]n (5, bpdb = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene) is a 3-dimensional structure contg. two-dimensional (2D) metal-carboxylate layer motifs, which are further pillared by cpop3- and bpdb ligands to complete the structure. [Zn6(cpop)4(azpy)2(H2O)4]n (6, azpy = 4,4'-azopyridine) manifests a unique quadruple layer structure constructed from two types of bilayered architectures linked by Zn2+ ions and bridging azpy ligands. Solid-state properties such as thermal stability and the photoluminescence properties at room temp. for these complexes also were systematically studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XosFamsA%253D%253D&md5=9235b204d2cb4ece3be465f7d76bc7ba
      54. 54
        Rowsell, J. L. C.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 1304– 1315
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        54
        Effects of Functionalization, Catenation, and Variation of the Metal Oxide and Organic Linking Units on the Low-Pressure Hydrogen Adsorption Properties of Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (4), 1304-1315CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The dihydrogen adsorption isotherms of eight metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), measured at 77 K up to a pressure of 1 atm, were examd. for correlations with their structural features. All materials display approx. Type I isotherms with no hysteresis, and satn. was not reached for any of the materials under these conditions. Among the six iso-reticular MOFs (IRMOFs) studied, the catenated materials exhibit the largest capacities on a molar basis, up to 9.8 H2 per formula unit. The addn. of functional groups (-Br, -NH2, -C2H4-) to the phenylene links of IRMOF-1 (MOF-5), or their replacement with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene moieties in IRMOF-20, altered the adsorption behavior by a minor amt. despite large variations in the pore vols. of the resulting materials. But replacement of the metal oxide units with those contg. coordinatively unsatd. metal sites resulted in greater H2 uptake. The enhanced affinities of these materials, MOF-74 and HKUST-1, were further demonstrated by calcn. of the isosteric heats of adsorption, which were larger across much of the range of coverage examd., compared to those of representative IRMOFs. Probably under low-loading conditions, the H2 adsorption behavior of MOFs can be improved by imparting larger charge gradients on the metal oxide units and adjusting the link metrics to constrict the pore dimensions; however, a large pore vol. is still a prerequisite feature.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XitV2msg%253D%253D&md5=76a0797beec956e59ca2ddf029f5a386
      55. 55
        Humphrey, S. M.; Chang, J.-S.; Jhung, S. H.; Yoon, J. W.; Wood, P. T. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2007, 46, 272– 275
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        55
        Porous cobalt(II)-organic frameworks with corrugated walls: structurally robust gas-sorption materials
        Humphrey, Simon M.; Chang, Jong-San; Jhung, Sung Hwa; Yoon, Ji Woong; Wood, Paul T.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (1+2), 272-275CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The porous coordination solids CUK-1 (Co purple, C gray, N blue, O red/pink) and CUK-2 are synthesized from unsym. ligands and CoII ions. Even after the removal of cocrystd. guests, the host frameworks are exceptionally stable. CUK-1 shows a high capacity for H2 adsorption and is one of very few materials capable of sepg. N2 from O2. Crystal structures of the above compds. have been described.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXis1WltQ%253D%253D&md5=1a503b3a7f66fa4255442136bc167823

        Rowsell, J. L. C.; Millward, A. R.; Park, K. S.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126, 5666– 5667
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        56
        Hydrogen Sorption in Functionalized Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Millward, Andrew R.; Park, Kyo Sung; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (18), 5666-5667CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Five porous metal-org. frameworks based on linking zinc oxide clusters with benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate, naphthalene-2,6-dicarboxylate, 4,5,9,10-tetrahydropyrene-2,7-dicarboxylate, 2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene-1,4-dicarboxylate, or benzene-1,3,5-tris(4-benzoate) were synthesized in gram-scale quantities to measure their hydrogen uptake properties. Hydrogen adsorption isotherms measured at 77 K show a distinct dependence of uptake on the nature of the link. At 1 atm, the materials sorb between 4.2 and 9.3 mols. of H2 per formula unit. The results imply a trend in hydrogen uptake with the no. of rings in the org. moiety.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXjt1ajur0%253D&md5=e58df7476eb6721e8c16cfaf80d0932d
      57. 57
        Kaye, S. S.; Long, J. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127, 6506– 6507
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        57
        Hydrogen Storage in the Dehydrated Prussian Blue Analogues M3[Co(CN)6]2 (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn)
        Kaye, Steven S.; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (18), 6506-6507CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The porosity and hydrogen storage properties for the dehydrated Prussian blue analogs M3[Co(CN)6]2 (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) are reported. Argon sorption isotherms measured at 87 °K afford BET surface areas ranging from 560 m2/g for Ni3[Co(CN)6]2 to 870 m2/g for Mn3[Co(CN)6]2; the latter value is comparable to the highest surface area reported for any known zeolite. All six compds. show significant hydrogen sorption at 77 °K and 890 torr, varying from 1.4% and 0.018 kg H2/L for Zn3[Co(CN)6]2 to 1.8% and 0.025 kg H2/L for Cu3[Co(CN)6]2. Fits to the sorption data employing the Langmuir-Freundlich equation give max. uptake quantities, resulting in a predicted storage capacity of 2.1% and 0.029 kg H2/L for Cu3[Co(CN)6]2 at satn. Enthalpies of adsorption for the frameworks were calcd. from hydrogen isotherms measured at 77 and 87 °K and found to increase with M varying in the order Mn < Zn < Fe < Co < Cu < Ni. In all cases, the binding enthalpies, which lie at 5.3-7.4 kJ/mol, are higher than the 4.7-5.2 kJ/mol measured for Zn4O(1,4-benzenedicarboxylate)3.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXjt1OktL4%253D&md5=0da1da83179d4af3688fd993edd05f17

        Ma, S.; Zhou, H.-C. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 11734– 11735
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        A Metal-Organic Framework with Entatic Metal Centers Exhibiting High Gas Adsorption Affinity
        Ma, Shengqian; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (36), 11734-11735CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A metal-org. framework, H2[Co4O(TATB)8/3] (PCN-9, H3TATB = 4,4',4''-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyltribenzoic acid), contg. entatic metal centers, was synthesized and crystallog. characterized, and its gas adsorption was studied. The H2 and CH4 adsorption enthalpies of PCN-9 are among the highest reported thus far.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XosVChs7g%253D&md5=6263507a8d922d1e954f3282681c2275
      59. 59
        Suh, M. P.; Park, H. J.; Prasad, T. K.; Lim, D.-W. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 782– 835
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        59
        Hydrogen Storage in Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Suh, Myunghyun Paik; Park, Hye Jeong; Prasad, Thazhe Kootteri; Lim, Dae-Woon
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 782-835CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. MOFs have versatile structures, high surface areas and high pore vols. - they can be regarded as good candidate materials for H storage. There are many MOFs that have high H adsorption capacities at low temps., typically at 77 or 87 K. The highest H storage capacity reported so far is 99.5 mg/g at 77K and 56 bar for NU-100. However, the high H capacities of MOFs at cryogenic temps. decrease as the temp. increases to room temp. This is because the H adsorption in MOFs is weak physisorption and the interaction energies between the H mols. and frameworks are low. To develop MOFs as H storage materials that meet the U.S.DOE targets for an on-board hydrogen system, a serious challenge is still present in the design and synthesis of the MOF materials. We may expect that highly stable MOFs having a large surface area and pore vol., together with many open metal sites and embedded catalysts for hydrogen spillover, would provide some pos. results for H storage at ambient temp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs1GlsbjM&md5=dd1f08beefd27cce77d88e466551c1af
      60. 60
        Vaidhyanathan, R.; Iremonger, S. S.; Shimizu, G. K. H.; Boyd, P. G.; Alavi, S.; Woo, T. K. Science 2010, 330, 650– 653
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        60
        Direct Observation and Quantification of CO2 Binding Within an Amine-Functionalized Nanoporous Solid
        Vaidhyanathan, Ramanathan; Iremonger, Simon S.; Shimizu, George K. H.; Boyd, Peter G.; Alavi, Saman; Woo, Tom K.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 330 (6004), 650-653CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Understanding the mol. details of CO2-sorbent interactions is crit. for the design of better carbon-capture systems. Here the authors report crystallog. resoln. of CO2 mols. and their binding domains in a metal-org. framework functionalized with amine groups. Accompanying computational studies that modeled the gas sorption isotherms, high heat of adsorption, and CO2 lattice positions showed high agreement on all three fronts. The modeling apportioned specific binding interactions for each CO2 mol., including substantial cooperative binding effects among the guest mols. The validation of the capacity of such simulations to accurately model mol.-scale binding bodes well for the theory-aided development of amine-based CO2 sorbents. The anal. shows that the combination of appropriate pore size, strongly interacting amine functional groups, and the cooperative binding of CO2 guest mols. is responsible for the low-pressure binding and large uptake of CO2 in this sorbent material.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtlaqt7nP&md5=62d8612e2927fcca9d6903619e95b042

        Tuning MOF CO2 Adsorption Properties via Cation Exchange
        An, Jihyun; Rosi, Nathaniel L.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (16), 5578-5579CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The pore vol. and BET surface area of bio-MOF-1 (a), Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O·Me2NH2, is systematically modified via postsynthetic cation exchange with either tetramethylammonium, tetraethylammonium, or tetrabutylammonium cations to yield Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O·Me4N (b), Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O·2Et4N (c), and Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O·Bu4N (d), resp. The impact that pore vol. and BET surface area have on CO2 capacity is evaluated, and it is found that materials with intermediate porosity (b and c) have the largest CO2 capacities under the conditions studied.

        Millward, A. R.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127, 17998– 17999
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        62
        Metal-Organic Frameworks with Exceptionally High Capacity for Storage of Carbon Dioxide at Room Temperature
        Millward, Andrew R.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (51), 17998-17999CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) show high CO2 storage capacity at room temp. Gravimetric CO2 isotherms for MOF-2, MOF-505, Cu3(BTC)2, MOF-74, IRMOF-11, IRMOF-3, IRMOF-6, IRMOF-1 and MOF-177 are reported up to 42 bar. Type I isotherms are found in all cases except for MOFs based on Zn4O(O2C)6 clusters, which reveal a sigmoidal isotherm. The various pressures of the isotherm steps correlate with increasing pore size, which indicates potential for gas sepns. The amine functionality of the IRMOF-3 pore shows evidence of relatively increased affinity for CO2. Capacities qual. scale with surface area and range from 3.2 mmol/g for MOF-2 to 33.5 mmol/g (320 cm3(STP)/cm3, 147 wt %) for MOF-177, the highest CO2 capacity of any porous material reported.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1GktLnJ&md5=ad433b990b72836a16c8647c09ec85f2

        Thermodynamics of mixed-gas adsorption
        Myers, A. L.; Prausnitz, J. M.
        AIChE Journal (1965), 11 (1), 121-7CODEN: AICEAC; ISSN:0001-1541.
        Adsorption equil. for components in a gaseous mixt. can be calcd. by using only data for pure-component adsorption equil. at the same temp. for the same adsorbent. Predicted isotherms give good agreement with exptl. data for mixts. of CH4-C2H6 and of C2H4CO2 on activated C, and of CO-O2 and of C3H8-C3H6 on silica gel.

        Construction of a Polyhedral Metal-Organic Framework via a Flexible Octacarboxylate Ligand for Gas Adsorption and Separation
        Lin, Zu-Jin; Huang, Yuan-Biao; Liu, Tian-Fu; Li, Xiang-Ying; Cao, Rong
        Inorganic Chemistry (2013), 52 (6), 3127-3132CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A flexible octacarboxylate ligand, tetrakis[(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)oxamethyl]methane (H8X), has been used to construct a highly porous metal-org. framework (In2X)(Me2NH2)2(DMF)9(H2O)5 (1), which is comprised of octahedral and cuboctahedral cages and shows a rare (4,8)-connected scu topol. Gas adsorption studies of N2, H2 on the activated 1 at 77 K reveal a Langmuir surface area of 1707 m2 g-1, a BET surface area of 1555 m2 g-1, a total pore vol. of 0.62 cm3 g-1, and a H2 uptake of 1.49 wt.% at 1 bar and 3.05 wt.% at 16 bar. CO2, CH4, and N2 adsorption studies at 195, 273, 285, and 298 K and also ideal adsorbed soln. theory (IAST) calcns. demonstrate that 1 has high selectivities of CO2 over CH4 and N2. The resulting framework represents a MOF with the highest gas uptakes and gas selectivities (CO2 over CH4 and N2) constructed by flexible ligands.

        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        65
        Li-modified metal-organic frameworks for CO2/CH4 separation: a route to achieving high adsorption selectivity
        Xu, Qing; Liu, Dahuan; Yang, Qingyuan; Zhong, Chongli; Mi, Jianguo
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (2010), 20 (4), 706-714CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        In this work three Li-modified metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) were constructed from MOF-5, by substituting the H atoms with O-Li groups in the org. linkers. A multiscale approach combining grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation and d. functional theory (DFT) calcn. was adopted to investigate the sepn. of CO2/CH4 mixts. in these new Li-modified MOFs, as well as in a previously proposed Li-doped MOF-5 for hydrogen storage and the original MOF-5. The results show that the selectivity of CO2 from CH4/CO2 mixts. in Li-modified MOFs is greatly improved, due to the enhancement of electrostatic potential in the materials by the presence of the metals. One of the new Li-modified MOFs, chem-4Li, shows a higher CO2 selectivity than any other known MOFs. Therefore, this work provides a route to improve the sepn. performance of MOFs for gas mixts. with components that have large differences in dipole and/or quadrupole moments. In addn., the mechanisms for selectivity enhancement in the Li-modified MOFs were elucidated at the mol. level, and we found that the location of doped metals can change the adsorption sites for CO2, and in turn may change the active sites in MOFs when used as catalysts.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Understanding gas separation in metal-organic frameworks using computer modeling
        Liu, Da-Huan; Zhong, Chong-Li
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (2010), 20 (46), 10308-10318CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a new family of nanoporous materials that combine the advantages of both inorg. and org. materials with great variety in functionality, pore size and topol. Gas sepn. is one of the fields that the first practical application of MOFs may be applied to; however, the study of MOFs as adsorbents in gas sepn. is still in its early stage, and their sepn. characteristics are not quite clear. Here, we summarize the recent advances on gas sepn. in MOFs using computer modeling, and show how computer modeling can help to understand the sepn. characteristics of MOFs. In addn., several strategies are proposed to improve the sepn. efficiency of MOFs, which are expected to be useful for designing new MOFs with improved sepn. performance for targeted properties.

        Supramolecular Recognition. Terpyridyl Palladium and Platinum Molecular Clefts and Their Association with Planar Platinum Complexes
        Goshe, Andrew J.; Steele, Ian M.; Bosnich, B.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2003), 125 (2), 444-451CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Mol. receptors, consisting of either two parallel cofacially disposed terpyridyl-Pd-Cl+ or terpyridyl-Pt-Cl+ units, are described. Concerted rotation of these units about the mol. spacer can alter their sepn. between 6.4 and 7.2 Å to accommodate the dimensions of mol. guests. Neutral and anionic planar complexes of Pt(II) were studied as guests to det. if metal-metal interaction between the host and guest metals could stabilize host-guest assocn. With a neutral guest, host-guest formation is signaled by a color change from light yellow to deep red. For one of the anionic guests, a visible absorption band appears upon host-guest formation with the Pt receptor that is ascribed to transitions assocd. with a Pt-Pt interaction. The assocn. consts. found for the neutral guest with the Pd and Pt receptors are large, suggesting that metal-metal interaction contributes to the mol. recognition. The structures of the host-(neutral)guest complexes in soln. were detd. by 1H NOESY spectra. A crystal structure of the Pt host-(neutral)guest complex is the same as that found in soln. and confirms the presence of a Pt-Pt interaction. Temp.-dependent 195Pt NMR spectra in soln. provide a quant. est. of the conformational interconversions of the free Pt receptor.

        Three 8-hydroxyquinolato (q) boron compds. B(C2H5)2q (1), BPh2q (2), and B(2-naph)2q (3) have been synthesized by the reaction of 8-hydroxyquinoline with an appropriate BR3 compd. Compds. 1-3 emit a green-blue color at λmax = 495-500 nm when irradiated by UV light. The devices of 2 produce a yellow-green light with broad emission spectra, attributed to the formation of an exciplex of 2 with the N,N'-di-1-naphthyl-N,N'-diphenylbenzidine (NPB) in the hole transport layer while the intrinsic EL emission of compd. 3 was obsd. Both 2 and 3 were good electron transport materials in EL devices.

        Allendorf, M. D.; Bauer, C. A.; Bhaktaa, R. K.; Houka, R. J. T. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2009, 38, 1330– 1352
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        71
        Luminescent metal-organic frameworks
        Allendorf, M. D.; Bauer, C. A.; Bhakta, R. K.; Houk, R. J. T.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1330-1352CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review; metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) display a wide range of luminescent behaviors resulting from the multifaceted nature of their structure. In this crit. review we discuss the origins of MOF luminosity, which include the linker, the coordinated metal ions, antenna effects, excimer and exciplex formation, and guest mols. The literature describing these effects is comprehensively surveyed, including a categorization of each report according to the type of luminescence obsd. Finally, we discuss potential applications of luminescent MOFs. This review will be of interest to researchers and synthetic chemists attempting to design luminescent MOFs, and those engaged in the extension of MOFs to applications such as chem., biol., and radiation detection, medical imaging, and electro-optical devices.

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        72
        Novel Bis(4,4'-dipyridylamine) Ligand with a Flexible Butadiyne Linker: Syntheses, Structures, and Photoluminescence of d10 Metal Coordination Polymers
        Ding, Caixia; Li, Xing; Ding, Yubin; Li, Xin; Ng, Seik Weng; Xie, Yongshu
        Crystal Growth & Design (2012), 12 (7), 3465-3473CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        The design and syntheses of novel ligands are essential for developing coordination compds. with novel structures and interesting properties. The authors designed and synthesized a novel ligand bis(4,4'-dipyridylaminophenylene)butadiyne (L) by attaching two 4,4'-dipyridylamine moieties to a flexible butadiyne linker. Starting from this novel ligand, seven coordination polymers [Zn2L(HCOO)3(OH)]n (1), [Cd2L2Cl4]n·3nDMF·3nH2O (2), [CdLBr2]n (3), [Cd6L3(SO4)6]n·4nMeCN (4), [Hg2LBr4]n·3nCH2Cl2·nH2O (5), [Cu2LI2]n·0.5nCH2Cl2 (6), and [Ag2L(H2O)2]n(NO3)2n·2nH2O (7) were synthesized. Single-crystal x-ray diffraction analyses revealed that two forms of the ligand crystals, L and L·0.5DMF present straight and bent conformations, resp., because of the flexibility of the butadiyne unit. A rich structural diversity was obsd. for its d10 metal complexes. Complexes 1 and 5 present ladder-like structures. In complexes 2 and 4, the ligand mols. are linked by metal atoms to afford 3-dimensional supramol. structures. It is noteworthy that the 3-dimensional structure of complex 4 consists of interesting infinite {Cd6(SO4)6}∞ chains, whereas complexes 3, 6, and 7 exhibit 2-dimensional network structures. In the crystal of complex 7, each ligand links four metal ions and each Ag ion bridges two ligands, giving undulated 2-dimensional sheets with large cavities composed of 66-membered metallomacrocycles, which are interpenetrated by three other such 2-dimensional sheets, affording a 4-fold interpenetrated structure. In summary, the complex structures are dependent on the metal ions and the anions. The flexibility of the butadiyne moiety provides addnl. means for modulating the structures. Solid state photoluminescence of the free ligand and the complexes shows emission maxima within the range of 420-515 nm, which can be modulated by the conformations of the ligand in addn. to the variation of the metal ions and anions, and the introduction of the butadiyne unit has a bathochromic effect.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XntlOhtLk%253D&md5=61d2f0c25470dc15b88a26b10a44d1e2
